labels.title: Her Majesty, The Queen, Elizabeth II (Blue)
labels.subtitle: Polly Borland

text.content:
type C photograph on paper

Purchased 2021

Â© Polly Borland

In 1952, Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II (1926â€“2022) ascended the British throne. To commemorate her coronation a pink rose named â€˜Queen Elizabethâ€™ was bred by the American rose grower Dr Walter Lammerts, which has since been used to cultivate 30 additional varieties. Fifty years later, on the occasion of Her Majestyâ€™s 2002 Golden Jubilee, flowers once again became an important symbol for the monarch, seen here in the bold backdrop featured in Melbourne-born Polly Borlandâ€™s iconic photographic portrait. This time, the flowers were poppies, immortalised in Finnish brand Marimekkoâ€™s iconic Unikko wallpaper design, created by Maija Isola in 1964. One of the few photographers commissioned to take a portrait for the Jubilee, Borland was allowed five minutes for the shoot, which started as soon as the Queen was in front of the camera. â€˜All of a sudden, I see this woman, whoâ€™s a lot more petite than Iâ€™d imagined, a lot more beautiful than Iâ€™d imagined, a lot richer than Iâ€™d imagined,â€™ Borland says. â€˜I couldnâ€™t talk, I couldnâ€™t remember anything.â€™

audio.title: Polly Borland on Queen Elizabeth II
audio.transcript: All of a sudden I see this woman who's, like, a lot more petite than I'd imagined, a lot more beautiful than Iâ€™d imagined, a lot richer than I'd imagined, very glamorous. I couldn't talk, I couldn't remember anything, you know I went into this kind of other zone, and completely overwhelmed that all of a sudden the Queen is there who is differentiated by blood. You know, more than just fame, but this woman has a bloodline that is different. And even though I'm not a royalist I was like â€˜Oh my godâ€™. Finally when I found my voice I just started babbling on but she was in a hurry. She was late. She had to go and host a lunch and I'd been told she doesn't really like being photographed. So she just wanted to get it over and done with. And sheâ€™s in front of the camera and Iâ€™m still talking. And then all of a sudden, the minder calls, â€˜two minutesâ€™. And I hadn't taken one roll of film. So he completely stitched me up. And then I just went into total panic. Took one roll. And at one point, I needed her to step to the left and I couldn't think of left. So I was down on my knee, hands and knees, trying to grab her ankles. Luckily, my husband stepped in and said, â€˜No, ma'am, Polly means step to the leftâ€™, grabbed me and got me back behind the camera. I mean, the whole thing was just a total kind of joke. And then she sees the floral background and she goes, â€˜Oh, I like thatâ€™. And also the ring flash was super bright. So by the time she left, she said, â€˜Oh, I think you've blinded meâ€™. And it's a miracle that I got two good photos, a miracle. And that really was the end of my portrait career. Interestingly, even though it was sort of like, probably the pinnacle â€“ I was commissioned by the palace, she's probably one of the most famous women in the world â€“ it kind of was almost like, well, I've done that. And I don't really need to keep doing it.
audio.acknowledgements: This recording was made during interviews for the National Portrait Gallery's [_Portrait Stories_][1] series.\n\n [1]: /stories

audio.title: Her Majesty, The Queen, Elizabeth II (Blue)
audio.transcript:
This portrait _Her Majesty, The Queen, Elizabeth II (Blue)_ is a photograph created by Polly Borland in 2001. The image is a type C photograph on paper and measures approximately 60 cm high by 50 cm wide. It is surrounded by a wide white mount and narrow light wood frame and is glazed. Queen Elizabeth is at the centre of the image. She wears a bright-blue suit and stands against a flat backdrop with a striking pattern of large flowers.

The background is a Marimekko print of simplified flowers in blues and purples on a white ground. Each flower has rounded petals, a pale centre and a smaller black oval at its heart.

Queen Elizabeth stands front on looking at us. Her hair gleams silver and is combed neatly straight up, curving either side of her forehead in soft curls to just behind her ears. She wears round white pearl earrings.

Queen Elizabethâ€™s skin is creamy smooth, marked by fine lines across her forehead and around her eyes. Her eyebrows are full, light, and travel down, defining the outer edges of her eyes. A dusting of pale shimmering eyeshadow brightens her eyelids.

Queen Elizabethâ€™s eyes are sapphire blue. Her nose is straight, two creases run from her nostrils beneath full cheeks to the outer corners of her mouth. Her lips are painted a bright coral pink and are slightly parted, showing the top row of her teeth.

Three strands of matching pearls adorn her neck, resting against the silky blue fabric of her top. A star-shaped brooch, covered in brilliant white diamonds, is pinned to the left shoulder of her suit jacket. Her jacket has notched lapels and is single breasted, fastened together by 3 large round dark-blue pearlescent buttons. It has long sleeves and reaches to hip level. The colour is the same intense electric-blue with a soft sheen as her clothing beneath. However an intricate checkerboard pattern is woven into the fabric.

Queen Elizabethâ€™s arms are pulled close to her sides. Over her left forearm hangs the black patent leather strap of her handbag and on her wrist is a watch with a gold link band and slim round face. Queen Elizabeth holds her hands in front, the right clasping the left. The skin on her hands is warmer in tone than that of her face and neck. The backs of her hands are marked by age and her unvarnished nails are cut short.

The portrait is cropped at the lower edge just beneath Queen Elizabethâ€™s hands with only a narrow ribbon of her skirt and handbag included. 

Lucinda Shawcross September 2022

video.title: Polly Borland
video.transcript: - Everyone wants to know the story about the Queen. So the story about the Queen is, I'd been told that I was only going to get five minutes, because they were giving all these younger, untried photographers a shot at taking photos of the Queen. The remit was, we only got five minutes. And I had said, right from the beginning, could I bring in my own backdrops? And they'd said yes. So I took in the gold sparkly background, which I'd seen the fabric in an Anne Summers shop window. And then a friend of mine, Martin Grant, the fashion designer, had suggested the famous Marimekko fabric. We go in, we've got a truck, we've got all this equipment. And we set up two cameras, two backdrops, one in front of the other. The minder came in and I was given this protocol. I could curtsy see when she walked in, but I didn't have to. I could bow when she walked in, but I didn't have to. And I should call her ma'am. Spam, ham was how I was to remember ma'am, because I said, "No, surely it's 'marm'." "No, it's ma'am." So I went, okay. And then they said, "And you need to talk her through what you're going to do." I went, okay. And I said to him, "When are you going to start counting the five minutes?" "When she gets in front of the camera." I go, okay. So she walks in. All of a sudden I see this woman, who's a lot more petite than I'd imagined, a lot more beautiful than I'd imagined, a lot richer than I'd imagined, a lot, looking very glamorous. And all of a sudden I completely, I couldn't talk, I couldn't remember anything. I went into auto, but the problem was, I'd been given so many options of what that autopilot might look like. And I hadn't picked, thought any of them through, or which one I was.. so I was lost in this sea of choices and quick thinking that, but I couldn't think. And completely overwhelmed that all of a sudden, there's this, the Queenie's there. I went and shook her hand. I then stepped back. And rather than curtsying, I did what I call the Australian squat, which was, I just bent my knees. So I looked like a total idiot at this point. I introduced everyone, I got that bit right. And then I went into this, finally when I found my voice, I'm just babbling on. But she was in a hurry, she had been, she was late. She had to go and host a lunch. She just wanted to get that. And I'd been told she doesn't really like being photographed. So she just wanted to get it over and done with. Well, I talked, and I talked, and I talked, and she's moving closer to the point of where she needs to be. And she's in front of the camera, and I'm still talking. And then all of a sudden, the minder calls, "Two minutes!" And I hadn't taken one roll of film. So he completely stitched me up. Rather than saying, I'm going to start counting now, because he'd said to me, but I hadn't taken any pictures. Because he'd also told me that I had to tell her what I was going to do. So I had three minutes. And then I just went into total panic. Took one roll. The camera was even off kilter, like it was a mess. And at one point I needed to step to the left, and I couldn't think of left. So I was down on my hands and knees trying to grab her ankles. Luckily my husband stepped in and said, "No, ma'am,Â Polly means stepÂ to the left", grabbed me, and got me back behind the camera. The whole thing was just a total joke. One roll, and I thought , I better go to the other, he called four minutes or something and I'm like, oh my God. So then we do the next set up, and then she sees the floral background. She's fine with the sparkly gold, because it was golden jubilee. And she goes, ooh, like that. And also the ring flash was super bright, so by the time she left, she said, "Oh, I think you've blinded me." And she walked out the door. Apparently Prince Phillip had been in there the whole time. I didn't even see him. That's how disassociated from the experience I was. And it's a miracle that I got two good photos, miracle. And that really was the end of my portrait career. Interestingly, even though it was probably the pinnacle, it was almost like, well, I've done that, and I don't really need to keep doing that. So yeah, that's the story of the Queen. And luckily, I got two pictures out of it. So that's good, yeah.

labels.title: Siamese Smize (with Thai Ceramic Pattern)
labels.subtitle: Nathan Beard
labels.medium: digital print with printed synthetic polymer paint and Swarovski crystals

text.content:
digital print with printed synthetic polymer paint and Swarovski crystals on paper

Courtesy of Nathan Beard

Â© Nathan Beard

Nathan Beard often combines personal family archives and memories with broader cultural signifiers of his Thai heritage to explore the complexities of â€˜authenticityâ€™ and the diasporic experience. His suite of _Siamese Smize_ photographs feature manipulated family portraits found in the artistâ€™s motherâ€™s abandoned family home in Thailand. â€˜Smizeâ€™, slang for smiling with the eyes, is here amalgamated with â€˜Siamese Smileâ€™ â€“ a Thai tourism term from the 1980s used to describe the perceived friendliness that prevails as a Thai stereotype within a Western context. Beardâ€™s family members are bedazzled and partially obscured by Swarovski crystals arranged into Thai floral patterns traditionally found on ceramics and silks. Like Beardâ€™s accompanying sculpture _Noi_, these works, with their painstaking labour of application, memorialise the subjects of the portraits, honouring Beardâ€™s relation to them and to his own heritage.

labels.title: Heirloom
labels.subtitle: Nathan Beard and Kiana Jones (Studio Assistant)
labels.medium: silicone, paint, foam and jewellery belonging to the artist's late mother

text.content:
silicone, paint, foam and jewellery belonging to the artist's late mother

Courtesy of Nathan Beard

Â© Nathan Beard

Perth-born, Melbourne-based artist Nathan Beard draws on his Thai heritage to explore the porousness of culture and memory. Created in tandem, the sculptures _Heirloom,_ _Phuang Malai_ and _Noi_ are expanded forms of portraiture that pay homage to the artistâ€™s late mother, Noi_._ Beardâ€™s silicone sculptures _Heirloom_ and the newly commissioned work _Phuang Malai_ are fragmented limbs cast from the artistâ€™s own body, entangled with his motherâ€™s possessions: a pair of cheap earrings and her wedding band. These impossible configurations recall the intangible bond between parent and child, as well as the surreal, disembodied mannequins used in visual merchandising. Through these discordant yet entwined associations they question the fluidity of value and worth attached to personal objects. Dotted with fake orchids, the national flower of Thailand, _Phuang Malai_ further embeds this oscillation between authenticity, value, memory and identity.\n\n_Noi_ emulates the form of the _bai sri_: Thai floral tributes constructed from organic materials including flowers and banana leaves traditionally used to invoke good luck. Composed from Beardâ€™s late motherâ€™s clothes, the laborious and intricately folded and pinned structure of _Noi_ carries a reflective, devotional quality that celebrates Noiâ€™s personal taste and style.
oil on canvas\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the Estate of Leslie Walford AM 2013

A well-known figure in Sydney and Southern Highland social circles, Dora Byrne (1895â€“1972) was an active fundraiser, organising balls and dinners for the Childrenâ€™s Hospital, the Crown Street Womenâ€™s Hospital and the Sydney Industrial Blind Institution. Photographs of her fashionable charity balls were regularly published in the society pages, with Byrne often adorned with living blooms. In a 1936 photograph reproduced in the Australian magazine _The Home_, for example, Byrne is pictured in a silk tulle dress with a white camellia in her hair and a spray of white orchids trailing over her shoulder. In this striking portrait by then in-demand portrait painter Richard von Marientreu, commissioned by Byrne herself, she wears a black off-the-shoulder gown with swathes of blush tulle draped over both arms. Her hands delicately caress a pale pink rose symbolising love, appreciation and gratitude.

labels.title: Noi
labels.subtitle: Nathan Beard
labels.medium: repurposed clothes belonging to the artist's late mother, steel, floristry foam, plaster, dressmaking pins

text.content:
repurposed clothes belonging to the artist's late mother, steel, floristry foam, plaster, dressmaking pins

Courtesy of Nathan Beard

Â© Nathan Beard

Perth-born, Melbourne-based artist Nathan Beard draws on his Thai heritage to explore the porousness of culture and memory. Created in tandem, the sculptures _Heirloom,_ _Phuang Malai_ and _Noi_ are expanded forms of portraiture that pay homage to the artistâ€™s late mother, Noi_._ Beardâ€™s silicone sculptures _Heirloom_ and the newly commissioned work _Phuang Malai_ are fragmented limbs cast from the artistâ€™s own body, entangled with his motherâ€™s possessions: a pair of cheap earrings and her wedding band. These impossible configurations recall the intangible bond between parent and child, as well as the surreal, disembodied mannequins used in visual merchandising. Through these discordant yet entwined associations they question the fluidity of value and worth attached to personal objects. Dotted with fake orchids, the national flower of Thailand, _Phuang Malai_ further embeds this oscillation between authenticity, value, memory and identity.\n\n_Noi_ emulates the form of the _bai sri_: Thai floral tributes constructed from organic materials including flowers and banana leaves traditionally used to invoke good luck. Composed from Beardâ€™s late motherâ€™s clothes, the laborious and intricately folded and pinned structure of _Noi_ carries a reflective, devotional quality that celebrates Noiâ€™s personal taste and style.

tempera on masonite

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Rob and Paula McLean 2011 Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program

Â© Charles Blackman/Copyright Agency, 2024

_The chase_ is one of several self portraits Charles Blackman painted in Melbourne in the early 1950s. In the portrait he depicts himself holding a flower in each hand, one living and one dead. Art historian and curator Felicity St John Moore described the paintingâ€™s imagery as an â€˜either-or choice between creation and spiritual deathâ€™. Blackman often used flowers to explore themes such as vulnerability, innocence and alienation. Reflecting on his fascination for flowers, he said: â€˜the flowers evoked the people, in a certain kind of gentility, or substance, or reverence, or sensitivity â€¦ almost like â€¦ the flowers gave the person the identity as well as the person gave the flowers the identity.â€™

audio.title: Charles Blackman
audio.transcript: When I first sort of, ten years I painted, I painted in a very emotional way, that is, that I worked from 9 oâ€™clock in the morning till 11 oâ€™clock at night painting like crazy. But it was not really a sort of disciplined thing, it wasnâ€™t really a thought-out thing. It was a thing where it was chasing a substance, it was kind of style chasing a substance. Once the substance was realised in some sort of sense, then the operative thing was to make it function properly, make it function fully. Itâ€™s like, sort of, driving a little baby Austin, finally you become a mature enough driver to be able to run an E-type Jag or a very complex piece of machinery. You have the emotional equipment realised, but it is then to make it a public fact, it is then to make it kind of articulate, a real articulate message in plastic terms, that is, it must be, the feeling must be couched properly in paint, the image must be embedded properly in the paint, must be trapped, as Francis Bacon says very well, in the paint.\n\nWell, now I work not so haphazardly, get up very early in the morning, go to the studio, clean up all the brushes, tidy up the room, sweep the floor and start working in a very detached sort of way, and work through disinterest to interest, or work, labour, very long hours on making a painting function within itself in a fairly detached sort of way. But this only could have been done by this kind of organic growth of the personality, it couldnâ€™t have been done in the artificial sense, you canâ€™t outside impose thoughts, they have to grow.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Charles Blackman is from the De Berg CollectionÂ (interview by Hal Missingham) in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

labels.title: Clifton Pugh painting in the studio
labels.subtitle: Fred Williams

text.content:
oil on canvas

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Lyn Williams AM 2011 Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program

Â© Fred Williams

Fred Williams OBEâ€™s unique approach to landscape emerged in the late 1950s, after his return from a period of study and work in London. The 1960s saw an increasing minimalism in his paintings, in which he sought to evoke the scale of the Australian landscape through canvases of a single colour dotted with tiny flecks of paint bisected by abrupt horizons. Williams applied the same stark approach to his portraits, which were often of his friends. He met artist Clifton Pugh AO (1924â€“1990) after his return from England. The friends painted together often, and for a time Williams lived and worked at Pughâ€™s bushland retreat, Dunmoochin. Williams made this portrait following Pughâ€™s first heart attack in 1974, after which he convalesced in the Williamsâ€™ house in Hawthorn. In his monograph on Williams, Patrick McCaughey writes that the artist has captured â€˜a touching combination of premature age and residual strengthâ€™ in his friend. The work is characteristically enlivened with touches of vibrant colour on the flowers in the foreground and Pughâ€™s hair.

audio.title: Clifton Pugh
audio.transcript: There was a wild herd of kangaroos in the bush around us, and of course I was very intrigued. I used to creep up and sit down and watch them playing around me. But always very upset because whenever they were aware of me, theyâ€™d gallop off, and I used to feel, if I could let them know that Iâ€™m not going to harm them. But perhaps because of other human beings they were scared. And my feeling the whole time was, if I could only get the birds and animals to realise that Iâ€™m not going to harm them.\n\nI saw one kangaroo had been shot and I was really upset about this and I used to go back and look at this â€“ remains. Then I got a shock the following spring, that the animal had practically disintegrated, but out of that area where this animal had died, there were these most beautiful orchids. And that gave me the realisation of this continuing cycle, is that this kangaroo had to die to produce something in the soil that produced these orchids, because they werenâ€™t anywhere else, they were just in this one spot. So all the paintings from then on, right up â€˜til halfway through â€™64, were of birds and animals, and this continuing cycle, always the paintings took the form, organic form of a movement, you could almost call it like a circle, â€˜til this trip came up to the north-west, up to the Kimberleys. There I had a very, very big change of feeling. As I said before, I felt myself not belonging to the world â€“ we were some mistake. Going up there, I felt myself starting to belong for the very first time, and itâ€™s made a big change to the paintings, because now Iâ€™m painting human beings, theyâ€™re in all the paintings Iâ€™m doing, because for the first time perhaps, at the age of 40, Iâ€™m feeling myself starting to belong in the world, that is, the world in its total stage, not just human beings and animals but all being one.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Clifton Pugh is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

text.content:
oil on board

Gift of Barbara Blackman 2000. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Charles Blackman/Copyright Agency, 2024

By the end of the 1970s, Charles Blackman OBEâ€™s status as a premier Australian artist was cemented. Perhaps best known for his signature series of paintings incorporating schoolgirls with flowers and _Alice in Wonderland_ figures and motifs, he exhibited prolifically throughout his career. Blackmanâ€™s _The family_ is an intimate portrait that depicts close family friends, poet and author Judith Wright, her husband journalist and playwright Jack McKinney, and their daughter Meredith. The work fondly recalls a day when Blackman, his wife, the author Barbara Blackman, and the Wright/McKinney family picnicked at Cedar Creek near the flower farms of Mount Tamborine in Queensland in the winter of 1955. Central to the composition are flowers that partially obscure Wrightâ€™s face and are repeated in Meredithâ€™s hat. Flowers were a recurring motif for Blackman, particularly white daisies, which often appear as a symbol of transience in his works.

audio.title: Audio description - The Family
audio.transcript:
The Family was painted by Charles Blackman around 1955. It is oil on board and measures about one metre high by 1.4 metres wide in its frame. The frame is narrow light wood with a stepped surface. This dark shadowy portrait shows the heads and shoulders of, in a row from the left: Jack McKinney, Judith Wright, and their daughter Meredith McKinney. They are painted in a distinctive stylised manner. 

The background is divided horizontally; the top fifth is painted pale cream and the lower part, behind the figures, is a mixture of dark browns and greys. The focus is on the figuresâ€™ faces and hats.

Jack, on the left, wears a hat with a square box-like crown in washed-out blue above a round reddish brim. His face is blue and almost rectangular. His eyes are on a slant. The eye on our left is lower and larger than the other. Below a dark brow, it is an elongated green almond with a large black iris. The eye on the right is higher on the face, set beneath the hat brim; blue with a black iris and a flash of orange highlighting the eyelid. The straight edges of Jackâ€™s nose run parallel to his cheek. His ear on the far left of the portrait is a loop of apricot and blue with a dark centre. Just below the ear, a hand rests on Jackâ€™s shoulder. The lower part of his face and neck is obscured by deep shadow, only interrupted by a sprig of blue-green foliage. 

The central figure, Judith, appears shorter than Jack. Her hat with its much flatter rounded crown and narrow brim does not stand as tall as his. The hat is blue and white striped with dashes of red, orange, and green. Judithâ€™s eyes sit in shade under its brim. They are wide-spaced, blue, with pointed inner corners. Their black irises are positioned towards their rounded outer ends. Just beneath Judithâ€™s eyes, a bunch of flowers of different shapes, sizes, and bright colours, hides the half of her face to our left. On the right her face is painted with smudges of white and pink. A pale haze on either side of her face suggests hair. 

Between Judith and Meredith, on our far right, is another brightly coloured bouquet. This seems to be held by one of the figures' hands at the very bottom edge of the portrait.

Meredith, on the far right, is smaller and shorter than her parents. Her hat has a square crown with a dome fitted within it sitting on a narrow brim. The hat is patterned with blue, white, yellow, and orange flowers. Beneath the hat is a dark band of shadow concealing Meredithâ€™s eyes. Her face, with grey and white skin, tapers with straight lines to a square chin. Her nose is triangular with a narrow bridge widening out to large, rounded nostrils. Meredithâ€™s lips are small and closed, crimson, outlined with black. On either side of her face is an irregular elongated blue-grey shape, possibly representing hair. In front of her chest is a mass of yellow and blue swirls. Meredith wears a white pointed collar and a floral-patterned top with yellow highlighting her shoulder on the far right of the portrait.
audio.attribution: Audio description written and voiced by Lucie Shawcross, 2021

video.title: The Family
video.transcript:
**Meredith McKinney:**Â Charles Blackman was staying with us in the mid 50â€™s, and as far as I can gauge the portrait called The Family would have come out of that particular time.Â My parents met in Brisbane just after the war, and in the beginning it was a very clandestine relationship because he was still married.Â But it was such a powerful relationship that in the end she simply decided to cut her losses and move in with him, and have a child, and take the consequences socially.Â And in those days they were pretty strong consequences.

My sense of childhood, which of course is hindsight, and everybody paints their childhood with hindsight, but my sense of it is just of a kind of a circle, a perfect circle.

Really, for Charles my father was probably â€¦ well, to say â€œfather figureâ€ is a very simplistic thing, but the talks that he and my father had were things that sort of drew Charles into new and exciting directions.Â The memories, I suppose, of that time are particularly intense of his working as an artist.Â I was very intrigued by his being an artist at that stage, because I hadnâ€™t even gone to school, and the thing I most wanted to do was draw, as one does before one can write.

So I remember the portrait that he did of me very well, taking me into a room and setting me up at one end of the room and saying, â€œWeâ€™re both going to sit and draw for the day.â€Â And so I drew at one end, and he drew at the other end, and after a while I went over to see what he was drawing, and was astonished and appalled to discover that it was me.

text.content:
gelatin silver photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 2003. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Lewis Morley Archive LLC

Margaret Olley ACâ€™s (1923â€“2011) intimate, brilliantly coloured interiors and still lifes always feature flowers. These portraits of Olley by Adam Knott and Lewis Morley were taken in her infamous Paddington home and studio, bursting with the flowers, fruit, artworks and artefacts in which she found endless inspiration. She was known to never throw anything out, and wilted and dried-out floral arrangements can be seen alongside fresh-cut flowers in the photographs. As Olley once said, â€˜If the house looks dirty, buy another bunch of flowers is my adviceâ€™. Her legacy is not only as a painter but as an arts patron and benefactor: since its foundation in 1990, the Margaret Olley Art Trust has donated many Australian and international artworks to public collections nationwide. Tweed River Art Gallery is home to the Margaret Olley Art Centre, which includes a recreation of Olleyâ€™s studio and living space. In Knottâ€™s portrait, Olley is photographed with her aunt, Mrs Knight.

audio.title: Margaret Olley
audio.transcript:
I have many ways of working. One is working directly from a model or from using a still life. This I donâ€™t arrange and then paint it immediately; I always have a very definite idea what I want to do. Sometimes it doesnâ€™t come off immediately, sometimes it does, and this is a very satisfying thing. Other times I paint say for a whole day, and then leave it for several weeks; it might go on for months or even six weeks, taking out something, repainting again.

I very rarely make a detailed sketch of what I intend to do. I might make little thumbnail notes but never very detailed, because I feel you kill the painting you want to do.

Painting to me is like drawing; you draw with your brush or your palette knife, so whether one is using a paintbrush or watercolour or a pen, itâ€™s all creative, and I never mind which medium Iâ€™m using.

The paintings I do are naturally things I â€“ Iâ€™m inspired whether itâ€™s the colour, the shape; it might be the colour of the skin of a native woman, it doesnâ€™t matter.

I can hear myself saying things that are so trite, and theyâ€™re not really how I want to say them. This is a dreadful thing for a painter. We say it in paint, otherwise weâ€™d be a writer or perhaps a musician, who knows?
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Margaret Olley is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

text.content:
type C photograph on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of The Hammond Care Group 1999

Â© Adam Knott

Margaret Olley AC (1923â€“2011), painter, was born in Lismore and studied art at East Sydney Technical College and the Grande ChaumiÃ¨re in Paris. She was well-known on the Sydney post-war art scene and her portrait was painted by both Russell Drysdale and William Dobell. Dobellâ€™s portrait of Olley, dressed in a gown fashioned from surplus wartime parachute silk, won the 1948 Archibald Prize. Olley held her first one-person show that year. It was a sell-out, and from that beginning, she held at least one solo exhibition annually. The Art Gallery of New South Wales honoured her long career with a major retrospective show in 1996â€“1997. In 1990, she endowed the Margaret Hannah Olley Art Trust, which has funded acquisitions by many Australian institutions including the National Portrait Gallery. One of Sydneyâ€™s most recognisable arts identities, in 2011 she was again the subject of an Archibald Prize-winning portrait, this time by Ben Quilty. In March 2014, almost three years after Olleyâ€™s death at age 88, the Tweed Regional Gallery opened its Margaret Olley Centre, which includes re-creations of rooms from the late artistâ€™s legendary Sydney home.

audio.title: Margaret Olley
audio.transcript:
I have many ways of working. One is working directly from a model or from using a still life. This I donâ€™t arrange and then paint it immediately; I always have a very definite idea what I want to do. Sometimes it doesnâ€™t come off immediately, sometimes it does, and this is a very satisfying thing. Other times I paint say for a whole day, and then leave it for several weeks; it might go on for months or even six weeks, taking out something, repainting again.

I very rarely make a detailed sketch of what I intend to do. I might make little thumbnail notes but never very detailed, because I feel you kill the painting you want to do.

Painting to me is like drawing; you draw with your brush or your palette knife, so whether one is using a paintbrush or watercolour or a pen, itâ€™s all creative, and I never mind which medium Iâ€™m using.

The paintings I do are naturally things I â€“ Iâ€™m inspired whether itâ€™s the colour, the shape; it might be the colour of the skin of a native woman, it doesnâ€™t matter.

I can hear myself saying things that are so trite, and theyâ€™re not really how I want to say them. This is a dreadful thing for a painter. We say it in paint, otherwise weâ€™d be a writer or perhaps a musician, who knows?
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Margaret Olley is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

text.content:
gelatin silver photograph on paper

Gift of Patrick Corrigan AM 2004. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Gregory Weight/Copyright Agency, 2024

Rosemary Valadonâ€™s (b. 1947) large-scale oil paintings are characterised by theatricality and opulence, feminist agency and vitality. Between 1990 and 1996 she completed _The Goddess Series_, portraits of Australian women as mythological/archetypal figures, referring to them as â€˜a testimony to the goodness and healing powers of womenâ€™. In this series, Valadon often used plants and flowers as iconography to portray her sitters, which can be seen in her portrait of sculptor Frances Joseph as Gaia, the Greek goddess of the earth. The 1991 Portia Geach prize-winning work hangs behind Valadon in her portrait by Greg Weight.

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Gift of Patrick Corrigan AM 2004. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Gregory Weight/Copyright Agency, 2024

Joshua Smith studied sculpture with Rayner Hoff and took classes in drawing and painting at Julian Ashton's Sydney Art School. During the war, Smith worked in a camouflage unit with fellow artist William Dobell. In January 1944 Dobell's portrait of Smith was awarded the Archibald Prize for 1943. A law case ensued, with the artist complainants alleging that Dobell's work was a caricature of his friend. The court found that it was a good likeness. The trial was inevitably distracting, embarrassing and debilitating for Dobell and Smith, but the following year Smith rallied to win the Archibald himself, for a portrait of HS Rosevear. Dobell's portrait of Smith was badly damaged in a fire in 1958, but it has since been restored. Smith painted several memorable portraits, including one of Dame Mary Gilmore and a haunting study of his parents acquired by the Art Gallery of NSW in 1943. He was a regular exhibitor in the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman Prizes for many years.

audio.title: Joshua Smith
audio.transcript:
The procedure for the portrait: Mr Rosevear came to the home and I painted it in our breakfast room where mother would prepare tea in between sittings. If I remember correctly, I asked for about 15 sittings. Being the first official portrait that Iâ€™d been given from the Government I was rather a bit scared, you know. Anyway, Mr Rosevear was very co-operative, and it eventually won the Archibald, so, quite good!

Now with my own procedure as regards portrait painting, that has varied considerably over the years. At one stage, I used to make a small drawing, say about 15 inches deep, in pencil, and more in the nature of a very accurate map, and then work from that; but later I found that I prefer to draw straight onto the canvas with charcoal, just dust that off and then paint direct. And I also like to have my sitter in front of me the whole time.

Now Iâ€™ve been asked to say something about Chips Raffertyâ€™s portrait and how I did it. Well that was painted out in the open in the lawn in his backyard. I had a good many sittings. I remember Chips saying to me, â€˜Youâ€™ve worn a track across my lawn, running backwards and forwards!â€™. I like to have my canvas right alongside my subject and get back from it to make my observations as far as possible.

Now Iâ€™ve been asked about any particular highlights in my life. Well, I think one of the most important things that I can remember is my first sale of a drawing. And it was a little drawing of my mother, a pencil drawing of my mother playing the piano. And we had it in the Julian Ashton School sketch club. And I was sitting next to the late Julian Ashton and Julian turned to me and said, â€˜Would you take half a guinea for it?â€™. I said â€˜Sold!â€™.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Joshua Smith is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

labels.title: Portrait of Henry Vernon Crock AO
labels.subtitle: David Smith

text.content:
oil on canvas

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Henry Vernon Crock AO in memory of David Smith 2007 Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program

Â© David Smith

This portrait of Australian surgeon and educator Henry â€˜Harryâ€™ Crock AO (1929â€“2018) was painted by British artist David Smith, in the artistâ€™s home in London. With a career spanning five decades, Crock was recognised as one of the worldâ€™s leading orthopaedic surgeons. At the time the portrait was created, Crock was working as Honorary Senior Lecturer and Consultant Spinal Surgeon at Hammersmith Hospital. Reflecting the close friendship between artist and subject, Smithâ€™s portrait focuses on Crockâ€™s personality, creating a strong sense of a contemplative, learned and caring man whose career has been dedicated to healing. The work also alludes to Crockâ€™s longstanding love of the visual arts â€“ one of the artworks depicted in the background is a woodcut by Tate Adams in Smithâ€™s own collection. A single yellow tulip adds a soft touch to the otherwise strong verticals of the composition, echoing the subject of the portrait.

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the artist 2001. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program. The series 'David Moore: From Face to Face' was acquired as a gift of the artist and with financial assistance from Timothy Fairfax AC and L Gordon Darling AC CMG 2001.

Â© Lisa, Michael, Matthew and Joshua Moore http://davidmoorephotography.com.au/
gelatin silver photograph on paper\n\nGift of Patrick Corrigan AM and Barbara Corrigan 2008. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Margaret Prestonâ€™s (1875â€“1963) woodblock prints and paintings are distinctly Australian, and often include wildflowers, harbour scenes and images of Sydneyâ€™s growth as a modern metropolis. Preston drew inspiration from the bushland around her harbourside home in Mosman, and became a vigorous campaigner for her vision of a modern Australian art that recognised the unique beauty of native trees and flowers. As Preston noted, â€˜Each flower is individual, they never respond to being turned into bouquets, as roses and violets do. These flowers show form and colour in simple treatment.â€™ This portrait of Preston surrounded by olearias (daisy bush) in her Mosman garden was taken by Harold Cazneaux who, in his prolific 40-year career as a photographer, created a rich catalogue of Sydneyâ€™s mood and people, and produced many photographs that have since attained mythic status. Like many of Cazneauxâ€™s works, this one demonstrates his belief that the best portraits were achieved through photographing in the â€˜natural surroundings of your home and gardenâ€™.

labels.title: Maggie
labels.subtitle: Del Kathryn Barton
labels.medium: synthetic polymer paint and pigment liner

text.content:
synthetic polymer paint and pigment liner on French linen

Commissioned with funds provided by Hayley Baillie and James Baillie 2023

Â© Del Kathryn Barton

Del Kathryn Barton is one of Australiaâ€™s most celebrated contemporary artists, famous for her figurative paintings that feature fantastical characters posed against ornate backgrounds. Many of Bartonâ€™s intricate paintings are focused on women, often surrounded by an abundance of flowers, fruit and other symbols of femininity and female power. In _Maggie_, Barton combines a statuesque likeness of cook, restaurateur, businesswoman and media personality Maggie Beer AO (b. 1945) with a spellbinding and dream-like personalised symbology of the sitter. In making the work, Barton asked Beer to provide a list of two of her favourite fruit and vegetables from each season. The eight chosen ingredients, including peas, asparagus, peaches, quince, pomegranate and tomatoes, become pictorial elements woven around the central figure. They signify Beerâ€™s passions and personality in the same way that objects were used to identify saints in the history of art. Beer holds her favourite flower â€“ a yellow rose â€“ to her heart, a consciously romantic inclusion by the artist who described her impression that her sitter â€˜fills up a room with light and energy and generosityâ€™. The yellow rose represents friendship, joy and warmth, here adding to the energy radiating from the sitter.

inkjet print on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Purchased 2012

Â© Estate of Robert Rooney

Robert Rooneyâ€™s series of portraits of 1980s Melbourne arts identities included his gallerist Bruce Pollard (b. 1936), who established the Pinocotheca Gallery in a St Kilda mansion in 1967, and relocated it to an old hat factory in Richmond in 1970. Aside from Legge and Watters in Sydney, it was the only gallery in Australia showing experimental work in the late 1960s and 1970s. Among the more than 300 artists who showed there were Rooney, Peter Booth, Dale Hickey, Rosalie Gascoigne, James Gleeson, Bill Henson, Tony Tuckson and Stelarc. Many of the portraits in Rooneyâ€™s series were taken spur of the moment, such as this photograph of Pollard in a domestic setting, a vase of jasmine softening the wooden table littered with beer cans.

labels.title: Making Sense of Place #4 (Portrait of Professor George Seddon)
labels.subtitle: Peteris Ciemitis

text.content:
watercolour and pastel on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Marli Wallace 2010 Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program

Â© Peteris Ciemitis

While there are no plants or flowers apparent within this portrait itself, Professor George Seddon AMâ€™s (1927â€“2007) life was defined by them. Seddon was a polymath â€“ a professor of geology, the history and philosophy of science, and environmental science â€“ who radically rethought our relationship to the environment. He wrote popular books on the Australian landscape embracing diverse points of view, as well as practical guides to gardening. It was through his work as an urban designer that artist Peter Ciemitis first encountered Seddon, whose 1972 essay _Sense of Place_ the artist described as â€˜a must-read text to planners and designers of my generationâ€™. Documenting Seddonâ€™s experience and research into the Swan Coastal Plain in Western Australia (including its flora, soils and climate), _Sense of Place_ has since become a landmark Australian environmental publication. In the portrait, Ciemitis aimed to capture a sense of his subjectâ€™s connection to the landscape: â€˜It is not only a map of George but a reference to a map of place: the environment with which George is concerned.â€™

type C photograph on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the artist 2005

Â© Jane Varkulevicius

Clive Blazey (b. 1944) is the founder and managing director of the Digger's Club, Australia's largest gardening club, with about 40 000 members. He is author of The Australian Vegetable Garden: what's new is old and is presently working on The Australian Food Garden. Blazey and the Digger's Club are largely responsible for the rescue and re-introduction of heirloom vegetable seeds in Australia and lead the battle against the production and distribution of genetically engineered and hybrid crops. Clive and his wife Penny began the club in 1978 in their house at Albert Park. Their company Digger's aims to 'explore the relationship between growing and serving fresh food that is full of favour, fresh and inspirational.'

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Gift of Patrick Corrigan AM 2004. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Gregory Weight/Copyright Agency, 2024

Margaret Coen (1909â€“1993) is known for her vibrant still lifes of flowers and serene landscapes. Drawn to painting flowers, she once said: â€˜Flowers have a life of their own. Flowers arenâ€™t static, they move. Nasturtiums will turn right round to look at the light in a room. Movement in flowers is difficult to paint, but thatâ€™s the aim.â€™ Photographer Greg Weight took this portrait in Coenâ€™s light-filled home studio in the Sydney suburb of St Ives, where she lived for almost 40 years. Next to her is a vase of flowers freshly picked from her garden: azaleas, jasmine and native rock orchids.

labels.title: Portrait of Dame Elisabeth Murdoch
labels.subtitle: Australian Tapestry Workshop, Merrill Dumbrell (Weaver), Christopher Pyett (Photographer) and Normana Wight (Computer Treatment)
labels.medium: warp: cotton No.12 seinetwine; weft: wool and cotton

text.content:
warp: cotton No.12 seinetwine; weft: wool and cotton

Commissioned with funds provided by Marilyn Darling AC 2000

Â© Australian Tapestry Workshop

Dame Elisabeth Murdoch AC DBE (1909â€“2012) contributed unstintingly to cultural, educational, medical, environmental and community causes throughout her life. Born in Melbourne, she married newspaper proprietor Keith Murdoch in 1928 and moved to Cruden Farm near Langwarrin, where they raised their four children. In 1933 she joined the management committee of the Royal Children's Hospital, of which she was president from 1954 to 1965 and enabled the establishment of the Murdoch Children's Research Institute in 1986. She supported the work of the Walter & Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research, the Royal Institute for Deaf & Blind Children, the Burnet Institute and the Bionic Ear Institute. The first woman to serve on the council of the National Gallery of Victoria, she endowed the Dame Elisabeth Murdoch Sculpture Foundation, the Dame Elisabeth Murdoch Arboretum and the Australian Ballet, and supported a range of programs to assist prisoners, children in care and other marginalised groups.\n\nDame Elisabeth was integral to the founding of the Victorian Tapestry Workshop â€“ now the Australian Tapestry Workshop â€“ in 1976, making them the obvious choice to create her portrait for the Gallery's collection. Former ATW Director Sue Walker recalls that Murdoch took great interest in the creation of her portrait, 'exhibiting her famous, exuberant excitement at the completion of the weaving'.

audio.title: Dame Elisabeth Murdoch
audio.transcript:
This is a delicate mixed media portrait of philanthropist and founding patron of the Victorian Tapestry Workshop, Dame Elisabeth Murdoch, created in 2000 by the now-named Australian Tapestry Workshop. It measures approximately 145 centimetres by 125 centimetres. The image was composed by painter Christopher Pyett, adapted on computer by printmaker Normana Wight and woven on the loom by Merrill Dumbrell.

It is displayed hanging between a white backing board and clear Perspex cover.

Elisabeth is shown from the chest up, her body angled slightly to the right and facing front on. Behind her, the lush greenery of her garden at Cruden Farm, Langwarrin. Wool and cotton woven threads create a textured surface. Different colour threads in the weft are bundled together to produce a flecked effect, enhancing the texture and blending a palette of creams, pinks and greens together across the surface of the work.

Garden foliage fills the background in a simplified and abstracted design. At the top, deep olive-green tones give a sense of depth, transitioning downwards to a range of bright and dark greens and yellows marking abstracted leaves, branches, and shrubbery, and creams and soft pinks creating blossoms.

Elisabeth is positioned against this garden backdrop, seen from the chest up, facing forward while leaning back and towards the left.

Her warm creamy skin has sparse amounts of purples, pinks, and yellow-green threads interwoven, introducing colours used in the background and clothing. Her white hair is pulled back from her face in a loose fashion, tied at the nape of her neck, tendrils escaping. Her forehead is gently furrowed above white framed glasses. Elisabeth gazes outwards with violet eyes lined with gentle wrinkles and hooded eyelids. Her closed blush pink lips are relaxed and have deep crevices on either side above a soft chin. Her neck emerges from a collared blouse woven in an intricate floral pattern of pinks, purples, charcoal grey, white and cream.

Her left hand is pulled up to gently rest upon her upper chest. Elisabethâ€™s fingers are slightly splayed, swollen at the joints, showing signs of age and arthritis, revealing a wedding band and a plain faced silver wristwatch.

Audio Description written by Alana Sivell and read by Amy Middleby

video.title: Dame Elisabeth Murdoch
video.transcript:
**Sue Walker:** Well, Dame Elisabeth has been a most wonderful friend and supporter to me, and I was the Founding Director of the Victorian Tapestry Workshop, which began in 1976. And Dame Elisabeth Murdoch was of course the driving force behind the establishment of the workshop.

**Christopher Pyett:** I first met Dame Elisabeth at the Tapestry Workshop. She enjoys a sense of humour. She enjoys a joke, she enjoys being teased. We get on well like that.

**Sue Walker:** Well, when Andrew Sayers approached us with the idea of weaving a portrait of Dame Elisabeth, I thought it was enormously exciting. Chris Pyett seemed a very suitable person to be involved in this project. He spent time with her in the garden.

**Christopher Pyett:** We took a series of photographs totalling about 55, 60. The first series were of her wearing blue. A lot of her character is expressed in her clothing, and the blue she always wears for a formal occasion. I got her to change that, because it never really did her â€¦ you know, none of them look comfortable, do they? But when we got her into a patterned dress it fitted much better.

**Sue Walker:** Well, Dame Elisabeth is one of those exceptional people who have imagination and vision, huge human warmth, and then the capacity to follow that up, not only financially but also with their own personal encouragement.

**Christopher Pyett:** When I look at the portrait, and look at her eyes, I can just hear her saying to herself, â€œWhat on earth do they want a portrait of me for?â€

**Sue Walker:** Her warmth, her enthusiasm, her great joy and delight in everything we did, has just been one of the greatest things in my whole professional life.

**Christopher Pyett:** Her contribution to the life of Australia has been absolutely immense, so I think there should be a tapestry portrait of her all over Australia!

Â

text.content:
inkjet print on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the artist 2005

Â© Heide Smith

A linguist, historian and translator who was fluent in eight languages, Dymphna Clark (1916â€“2000) published many translations of books, including those by her husband, the historian Manning Clark. German-born photographer Heide Smith took this portrait of her friend clutching pink and white hellebores (Lenten roses) in the garden at Manning Clark House, in the Canberra suburb of Forrest. An advocate for the environment and a passionate gardener, Dymphna maintained large vegetable gardens in Forrest and worked with Greening Australia volunteers to plant over 1000 native trees at the familyâ€™s property at Wapengo on the NSW south coast.

inkjet print on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Purchased 1999

Â© Montalbetti & Campbell

Glenn Murcutt AO (b. 1936), architect, received the world's highest architectural honour when he was awarded the Pritzker Prize in April 2002. Having spent a good deal of his youth in New Guinea, where he learned to love simple shapes and materials, Murcutt only just scraped into a university architecture course at the University of New South Wales, graduating in 1961. As a student, he drew on principles he had learned while working for his father, who had a number of building businesses in Sydney after the war. Murcutt is unusual among Pritzker winners in that he works alone, mostly on residential homes; he has never made a skyscraper or a tourist attraction; and he uses mostly basic materials. By using shades, louvres, fully opening walls and carefully planned ventilation he enables his buildings to respond instantly to changing conditions and requirements. His overriding design philosophy is that dwellings should 'touch the earth lightly'. There are several books about his work, including _Leaves of Iron_ (1991) and _Touch This Earth Lightly_ (2000) by Philip Drew and _Glenn Murcutt: Buildings + Projects 1962â€“2003_ (2003) by FranÃ§oise Fromonot. Murcutt's Islamic Centre project, an unconventional mosque in suburban Melbourne, is at the heart of an intimate film about Murcutt by Catherine Hunter, _Glenn Murcutt: Spirit of Place_ (2016). He is a Professor at UNSW, and is the principle 'master' on the Architecture Foundation Australia annual International Architecture Master Classes.

audio.title: Glenn Murcutt
audio.transcript:
For me in architecture nature has a beautiful story. You look at the strength of our flora but also look at the delicacy at the same time. So thereâ€™s a strength and a delicacy. I love the idea of the legibility of the strength. I love the delicacy of the edges. And so in my work, I like to articulate that which is structure, that which is skin, that which is edge. These are things that are in nature in this part of the world and I have endeavoured in my career to try and understand this landscape of ours and be able to integrate these elements not in a determined way but in a very relaxed way. So that there is the articulation of elements without it being such that you are forced to look at it. I donâ€™t like an architecture that is saying to me, Look at me, look at me, look at me. I want an architecture thatâ€™s quiet, that reveals itself quietly, and the more you start to see it, the more you start to understand it.

The roots of architecture remain relevant. If you go beyond the roots of architecture, about space, about order, about structure, about understanding nature and structure â€¦ If you go and just do something for the sake of it, for example, youâ€™ll hear students talking about, Oh I wanted to do this and I wanted to do that. Thatâ€™s delinquent. What does the brief call for? What does the site call for? What does the economics call for? What does the structure call for, what are the materials available? These are the things â€“ itâ€™s not what I want. Itâ€™s what these things are asking to be addressed.

I am very happy at the age of over 80 now still practising like mad and still enjoying it as I did as a young architect.
audio.acknowledgements: This recording was made during interviews for the National Portrait Gallery's [_Portrait Stories_][1] series.\n\n [1]: /stories

text.content:
type C photograph on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Purchased 2000

Â© Polly Borland

John Farnham AO (b. 1949), singer-songwriter, tasted his first success in 1968 with the throwaway single 'Sadie'. He was voted Australia's King of Pop five years in a row between 1969 and 1973, when he also appeared in a variety of stage shows and musicals. His career stalled for the second half of the 1970s. He formed a band and went back on the performance circuit from 1982, briefly as the lead singer of the Little River Band, before returning to the charts with a version of the Beatles' song 'Help' in the mid-eighties. The solo record he released in 1986, _Whispering Jack_, became Australia's first CD album and the nation's biggest-selling album to date, going platinum 17 times on the domestic market alone. He was Australian of the Year in 1987; his albums _Age of Reason_ (1988) and _Chain Reaction_ (1990) both debuted at number 1. The genial Farnham remains one of Australia's best-loved celebrities, finishing high on the list of the ABC'S My Favourite Australian poll in 2008 and being recognised as \n\nAustralian of the Year in 1987.

inkjet print on paper

Gift of the artist 2019

Â© Robin Sellick

Robin Sellick was still an emerging photographer when he approached Australian politician Donald Allan Dunstan AC QC (1926â€“1999) to sit for this portrait. A leading campaigner for social reform, Dunstan served as the 35th premier of South Australia from 1967 to 1968, and again from 1970 to 1979, and was leader of the South Australian Branch of the Australian Labor Party from 1967 to 1979. Sellick turned up at Dunstanâ€™s Norwood home for the shoot with his artist friend Phillip â€˜Sundayâ€™ Hopkins, for moral support. Dunstan was dressed for the shoot but was encouraged by the pair to instead take a dip in the pool in his backyard. Sellick recalls that over the years numerous people have commented on the flower that looms large at the foreground of the frame, which is known colloquially as a Naked Lady. Despite its suggestive nickname, the Belladonna Lily is in fact a symbol of strength and endurance, and in this instance could perhaps be read as a testament to Dunstanâ€™s long and prosperous career in social reform.

type C photograph on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the artist 2003 Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program

Â© Lewis Morley Archive LLC

Anne Boyd AM (b. 1946), composer and teacher, was born in Sydney and studied composition with Peter Sculthorpe at the University of Sydney before earning a PhD at the University of York. She lectured in music at the University of Sussex before returning to Australia to take up an Australia Council grant that enabled her to work full-time as a composer between 1977 and 1981. She had already written one of her best-known works, As I crossed a bridge of dreams, which is part of the standard contemporary choir repertoire, but during this period she wrote various chamber works, the oratorio The Death of Captain Cook, and the choral symphony Coal River. In 1981 she became the founding head of Hong Kong University's Department of Music, and in 1990 Professor and Head of the Department of Music at the University of Sydney. While working in Hong Kong she wrote the children's opera The Little Mermaid for the Australian Opera. Boyd gained wider fame as a public advocate of increased funding for Australian universities as the focus of the Bob Connolly/Robin Anderson documentary Facing the Music in 2001.

audio.title: Anne Boyd
audio.transcript: One of my earliest musical experiences is the memory of my aunt playing the piano and singing in the adjacent lounge room to our â€“ well what was still called then the nursery, on this country property. Also, I used to listen to the radio a lot, in fact one of my favourite games was playing with the frequencies of radios and seeing what kinds of statics and sounds I could pick up, and of course, short wave was just fantastic and I was able to often, during the evening, pick up neighbouring Asian stations and so on, and this music really excited me as a child. Whenever I heard music I was always drawn to it. I had to go and listen to it. At about the age of six, my sister sent me a recorder and a teach-yourself manual so, of course, I taught myself to play the recorder in a very short time. This again was something which was very important to me as a means of expression and I, in fact, started writing quite â€“ well, bizarre scores, really the notation of which meant nothing to anybody except myself, but I used to derive a great deal of enjoyment from playing these weird symbols that Iâ€™d managed to put down onto paper.\n\nPerhaps my attraction to the sound of shortwave and the static and so on that was created by the radio is a result of my trips by air, the first one of which I undertook as a small child at the age of two. The sounds of the engines of the plane even fascinated me, and the variation in the contrasting timbres and dynamics of what happened when you were actually up in the air. I think probably my fascination with sound of all kinds was a result of living in a silent or a comparatively silent environment in the country, and so therefore these sounds of the city, of machines, of planes, in my rare contacts with them, are all the more meaningful to me.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Anne Boyd is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

text.content:
type C photograph on paper

Purchased 2005

Â© Simon Griffiths

Freshness is key to the career of fourth-generation Australian-Chinese chef, restauranteur, author and television presenter Kylie Kwong AM (b. 1969). Renowned for her exciting blend of Cantonese and Australian cuisine, Kwong is an advocate for native, organic and biodynamic ingredients, and uses food as a catalyst for positive social impact and cultural exchange. She learnt the finer points of Cantonese cooking in her mother Paulineâ€™s kitchen. At age 25, after a career in graphic design, Kwong apprenticed with Neil Perry at Rockpool, and within two years was made head chef at Perryâ€™s Wokpool. In 2000 she opened the restaurant Billy Kwong in Surry Hills with her friend, Bill Granger, taking over the restaurant a year later. It was a Sydney staple for 19 years. Kwong has collaborated with photographer Simon Griffiths on several books, including _My China: A feast for all the senses_ (2007) and _It Tastes Better_ (2010). Here she is captured by Griffiths in motion with a basket full of fresh produce and flowers, as if on the way home from the markets.

oil on canvas

Commissioned with funds provided by Marilyn Darling AC 2023

Â© National Portrait Gallery of Australia

In a career spanning over five decades, cook, restaurateur, food writer and philanthropist Stephanie Alexander AO (b. 1940) has inspired generations of home cooks and fundamentally transformed the way we think about food in this country. Her Fitzroy restaurant Stephanieâ€™s was a Melbourne institution for 21 years and her Stephanie Alexander Kitchen Garden Foundation has educated tens of thousands of children. Alexanderâ€™s 17 books include her bestselling _The Cookâ€™s Companion_, a staple in many Australian homes. In this portrait by Tsering Hannaford, Alexander is dressed in luxe purple florals. In addition to being Alexanderâ€™s favourite colour, purple evokes the forthrightness of the suffragettes. With her sustained commitment to wellbeing through an appreciation of fresh, homegrown food, Alexander has channelled her career into one of advocacy and community engagement.

type C photograph on paper

Gift of the artists 2005

Â© Murray Fredericks and Lisa Giles

Over a 40-year career in food, chef, restaurateur, farmer and author Matt Moran AM (b. 1969) has run celebrated restaurants, including the 2-hatted ARIA at Circular Quay, Chiswick and Chophouse. He has appeared on television in _MasterChef_, _My Restaurant Rules_ and _Matt Moranâ€™s Paddock to Plate_, and written bestselling cookbooks. His passion for quality, seasonal and locally sourced produce is reflected in this exuberant portrait by Murray Fredericks and Lisa Giles. A play on 16th-century Italian artist Caravaggioâ€™s _Boy with a basket of fruit_, Moran is classically posed and almost dwarfed by the abundance of fruit and blooms he carries.

type C photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 2017. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Ingvar Kenne

Alexis Wright (b. 1950), author and activist, won the Miles Franklin Award in 2007 for her novel Carpentaria and the 2018 Stella Prize for her collective memoir _Tracker_. A woman of the Waanyi nation of the Gulf of Carpentaria, Wright was raised by her mother and grandmother in Cloncurry, her non-Aboriginal cattleman father having died when she was five years old. Her first novel, _Plains of Promise_, was published in 1997 and was shortlisted for the Commonwealth Writers Prize, a New South Wales Premierâ€™s Literary Award and the Age Book of the Year. Throughout the ensuing decade Wrightâ€™s short stories and essays were included in a number of anthologies and in journals such as _Overland_, _Australian Humanities Review_ and _Southerly_, and her criticism appeared in _The Age_ and _Meanjin_, among other publications. _Carpentaria,_ a 500-page-long novel about an Aboriginal family from the Gulf, was written in a style incorporating â€˜the way we tell stories and in the voice of our own people and our own way of speakingâ€™, and was initially rejected by several publishers. On its eventual appearance in 2006, however, it won a slew of awards including the Victorian, New South Wales and Queenslandâ€™s Premierâ€™s Literary Awards for Fiction; the Australian Book Industry Award for Book of the Year; and the Australian Literary Societyâ€™s gold medal, in addition to the Miles Franklin. Her third novel The _Swan Book_ (2014) was also awarded the ALS gold medal and was shortlisted for the Miles Franklin and the Victorian and New South Wales Premierâ€™s Awards. In addition, through her work as a researcher, activist and consultant with various Aboriginal organisations, she has published widely on Indigenous issues and land rights in Australia and overseas. Her non-fiction titles as author and editor include _Grog War_ (1997), examining alcohol abuse in the Northern Territory, and _Take Power_ (1998), an anthology of writing on land rights in Central Australia. Wright has undergraduate qualifications in social studies and creative writing and a doctorate from RMIT. She is currently a Distinguished Fellow of the Writing and Society Research Centre at the University of Western Sydney.

audio.title: Alexis Wright
audio.transcript:
This is a photographic portrait of Aboriginal author and activist â€“ Alexis Wright. Photo by Ingvar Kenne, 2009.

The portrait is approx. one metre square showing a full length, standing view of Alexis in a blackened, burnt-out landscape of predominately bare trees.  
The upper half of the photograph features a pale, greyish-white sky with tall, burnt tree trunks extending up and out to the sky beyond. In the upper left corner, several trees twist and bend across each other.

In the background and halfway down the photo, the hazy curve of a distant hill crosses through the landscape. Numerous blackened and bare trees cover the sloping ground in front.

The figure of Alexis occupies the centre and lower half of the scene. To the left of Alexis and slightly behind, a large black tree trunk stands tall, reaching up and out beyond the portrait. Sprouting from the trunk are several bright green patches of leafy new growth. 

Alexis stands on a sloped area of ash covered earth, left blackened and charred by fire.  
She looks directly at us, eyes squinting, mouth closed, with a look of sadness or dismay. Her auburn shoulder length hair is slightly curly, and part of her fringe is swept back. A segment hangs raggedly on her forehead.

The left side of her body is angled slightly forward, and she wears a black round- necked top under a black zippered jacket. Her zipper open to mid-torso, the jacket lining and collar is a dark grey,. Both her hands are tucked into her practical jacket pockets. Her pale right hand is partly visible. 

Alexis wears long black pants and tan coloured moccasins.

Burnt branches, twigs and debris are scattered around her. 

**Audio description written by Pauline McCreath and voiced by Rory Walker**

text.content: inkjet photographic print on paper\n\nCourtesy of Sione MonÅ«

Sione MonÅ«â€™s multidisciplinary work often features themself starring in scenes of everyday activity. Their self portraits increasingly incorporate fake flowers, fashioned into _Aoâ€™ Kakala_ or cloud mask forms, as worn by the artist in _Ao Kakala Mask self portrait_ and _Aoâ€™ Kakala Mask_. Due to the scarcity of tropical flowers in Aotearoa/New Zealand, MonÅ« has pivoted to using vibrant plastic options sourced from local shops, thus honouring cultural traditions while also reflecting the adaptability inherent in diasporic life. The use of plastic beads link them back to the world of _leitÄ«_ â€“ individuals with a feminine gender expression. These vibrant adornments are used by the artist to suggest the performativity inherent in everyday life.

Based between Canberra and TÄmaki Makaurau/Auckland, Sione MonÅ« is a member of the Tongan diaspora. Much of their work is inspired by _nimameaâ€™a tuikakala_ or the Tongan fine art of flower designing, using _kahoa_ or floral garlands. An art form traditionally practised by women, MonÅ« began making their own using sticky contact paper and florals from the environment of each person they were making them for, resulting in their early series _Canberra Family Portraits_. These images were taken on the artistâ€™s smart phone â€“ a tool they often employ to document their life and as an extension their artistic practice, thus blurring the boundaries between the personal and the public.

type C photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 2017. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Ingvar Kenne

Ingvar Kenneâ€™s portrait of Australian fashion model Anneliese Seubert (b. 1973) evokes an uncanny synthetic quality enhanced by the bright lighting and cheery yellow chrysanthemums clasped in Seubertâ€™s outstretched hand. This effect lends the sitter a mannequin-like pallor and recalls the numerous glossy fashion spreads she has appeared in over the years. Seubert won the Ford Models Supermodel of the World competition in 1990, aged 17. Signing with the Paris-based agency Karin, she lived in Paris and then New York for the next two decades, walking the runway for Dior, Hermes, Yves Saint Laurent, Gucci and Versace, and appearing in editorials for magazines such as _Vogue_, _Marie Claire_, _Harperâ€™s Bazaar_ and _Elle_. Ingvar Kenne took this photograph during one of Seubertâ€™s regular trips home. In line with Kenneâ€™s deceptively simplistic and intimate style, there was no hairdresser or makeup artist for the shoot. As Seubert recalled: â€˜Iâ€™m like, â€œOh my god.â€ Worst nightmare. But I mean, the photos were beautiful, and it was quite an interesting shoot because it was full sunlight.â€™

video.title: Anneliese Seubert
video.transcript:
The previous year to the year I was in the Dolly Covergirl Competition, Kate Fischer had actually won it, and she was at the same school, at Girls Grammar. My friend said, "Well if she can win it, "you can win it too." So we took some photos and sent them in, and then I was a finalist. And my little blurb, I mean it's quite fashionable if you're into STEM, as everyone is these days, but my favourite subject was maths, and I loved skiing. Because I didn't win, I just started working on weekends and in school holidays. And I think I was in year 10 when I was in the competition, so through year 11 and 12 I gradually started working a bit more.

My first jobs were for a magazine called _Follow Me_. And then a couple of _Vogue_ jobs, _Harper's Bazaar_ was around then as well. When I was 17, I had an Australian _Vogue_ cover which was great, and some advertising clients, and off I went. I kind of did a preliminary trip when I was in year 12, I did the _Ford Supermodel Competition_, and I went to L.A. by myself. I won that competition and then went to New York for a couple of weeks, so I'd had a little taste of what it was going to be like, and then I went back to school.

So I finished year 12, and then off to Paris. And I just started going on castings. I thought I had great pictures in my portfolio, but people over in Paris looked at them and like, "hmm," you know, they're kind of a little bit, "daggy Australian," in a way. So I started working, got more pictures and then started doing shows. Then I got very busy traveling and... so many markets around, there's Paris, Germany, Spain, Italy. I was flying from one job to the next. Sometimes you didn't come home in between. But I was kind of just let free. I don't know if I'd do that with my kids now.

Back in the '90s, you would either get a telephone call from your agency in the afternoon before and check what you had to do for the next day, or sometimes you got a fax. You would have to go and visit a client and show them your pictures, maybe try on some clothes, talk to them about what you'd been doing. It's more of a collaboration. The client and the photographer, usually an art director as well. They will all say, "This is what we'd like." They often have reference images. They can tell you a story.

I used to do John Galliano's fashion shows. And he would always make this huge story, and each character, which was essentially each dress or outfit, had a story and a part in the story. So when you were walking around through the scene, the set, you would be imagining that you were this lady on the rooftop who was running away from something. There was always a little story. But I think there was a difference between putting on a Galliano dress, it just made you feel amazing. So just channeling that and thinking about how fabulous you look is really the way it works, I think. 'Cause if you don't believe it, no one else will.

When I was 24, I was based in Paris. I used to come home three times a year, so I was home for Christmas, home for August, and there was usually either I'd meet mum and dad somewhere, or I came home for an extra trip. And I often worked in Sydney while I was home, and the portrait that's hanging, it was funny, because I was so used to turning up at a shoot and having hair and makeup, and they would turn me into a different character. This time, they're like, "Oh no, we just want you." Like, what are you talking about? Where's the hairdresser? "Oh, we just want it to look like you did your own hair." Are you serious? And no makeup? "No, no, look how beautiful you are!" I'm like, "Oh my god." Worst nightmare. My hair is hard to do for a hairdresser at the best of times, so I was a little bit in shock. But I mean, the photos were beautiful, and it was quite an interesting shoot because it was full sunlight and flash, I think. So the lighting is quite harsh. There's definitely a difference between the light in Australia and the light everywhere else. And, yeah, I've got my little bunch of flowers.

text.content:
type C photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 2017. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Ingvar Kenne

Akira Isogawa (b. 1964), fashion designer, was born in Kyoto, Japan, and first came to Australia at the age of 21. After immigrating, he worked as a waiter while studying fashion design at East Sydney TAFE and Sydneyâ€™s National Art School. In 1993 he opened the Akira Isogawa boutique in Woollahra, and swiftly established a reputation for his bold and intelligent clothes. At Sydneyâ€™s Australian Fashion Week in 1996, he sent all his models out wearing red socks from Gowings because he couldnâ€™t afford shoes for them; but he has shown at every Fashion Week since, and since 1998 he has shown twice annually in Paris. He has exhibited at the Museum of Contemporary Art, and Sydneyâ€™s Object Galleryâ€™s exhibition of his construction techniques is said to have been its most successful ever show. The National Gallery of Victoriaâ€™s _Akira Isogawa: Printemps EtÃ©_ in 2004-2005 was the first solo exhibition of an Australian designerâ€™s work to be shown at one of its major art institutions and later toured to Singapore, Manila and Bangkok. In 2005 Isogawa was depicted on the â€˜Australian Legendsâ€™ series of postage stamps and in 2007 he was named the countryâ€™s first Fashion Laureate. He has designed costumes for four Sydney Dance Company productions and for the Australian Balletâ€™s production of Graeme Murphyâ€™s _Romeo and Juliet_ in 2010. Sydneyâ€™s Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences showed the retrospective _Akira Isogawa_ at 2018-2019. Since the Woollahra boutique closed in 2017, Australiaâ€™s only two Akira boutiques are in the Strand Arcade, Sydney, and Fortitude Valley, Brisbane.

audio.title: Akira Isogawa
audio.transcript: When I look back, being a teenager growing up in a traditional city in Japan called Kyoto, I felt I was a bit of a fashion victim, really. Well now actually I create fashion. But back then, actually, I was consuming fashion and that's how much I loved [it].  \nJapanese culture is so different from Western ones. My grandparents had a house next door. They were all wearing actually traditional clothes â€“ kimono. What I noticed about kimono is actually they're made out rectangular shaped cloth. And they have no shapes. Whereas actually, Western clothes has a particular shape that enhance, particularly actually for female, the femininity of female body, but whereas actually kimono is totally unisex. I mean, I've never actually designed kimono myself. But being a kimono designer, I imagine actually, they work on texture, colour, print, and so on, because it's a highly textile driven fashion, and then to me, that's what Japanese fashion is all about. You know, when I design my own collection, I never really force myself to express my Japanese entity, but I feel that it just comes up naturally. And I think what's interesting is that not just, you know, designing something so traditionally Japanese, but then I kind of actually manage to fuse with Australian ease I guess actually. Australia has got this particular attitude â€“ friendly to start with â€“ but it's quite actually casual about things, you know. I feel actually my design is a result of actually, you know, some Japanese heritage with Australian attitude, which is actually friendly and easy.
audio.acknowledgements: This recording was made during interviews for the National Portrait Gallery's [_Portrait Stories_][1] series.\n\n [1]: /stories
