inkjet print on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Purchased 2012

Â© Estate of Robert Rooney

In the late 1970s and early 1980s Robert Rooney took a series of 75 photographic portraits of the Melbourne art scene, often set in suburban houses or streetscapes. Rooneyâ€™s subjects included surrealist painter Peter Booth (b. 1940), who gained widespread recognition through the inclusion of his large architectural â€˜blockâ€™ paintings in the National Gallery of Victoriaâ€™s exhibition _The Field_ in 1968. Rooney captured Booth outside his studio with a cigarette; the bouquet of roses next to him innocuous against the concrete and corrugated iron of the inner-city landscape. Of the series Rooney wrote: â€˜These portraits were to be as perfect as I could make them. There were certain rules â€“ to use available light, no matter how dim (long exposures and a hand-held camera), and no cropping.â€™

labels.title: Study for a portrait of Dame Merlyn Myer DBE
labels.subtitle: Sir William Dargie CBE

text.content:
oil on masonite

Gift of the Estate of Marion Orme Page 2016

Â© Roger Dargie and Faye Dargie

Eight-time Archibald Prize winner Sir William Dargie CBE painted at least two portraits of Melbourne-born philanthropist Dame Merlyn Myer DBE (1900â€“1982). This portrait depicts the matriarch at ease on a floral-patterned sofa, wearing an elegant, yet relaxed, floor-length black kaftan. To her left is a simple vase filled with overblown pale pink peonies, which signify love, romance, affection and happiness. Following her husband Sidney Myerâ€™s death in 1934, Myer established the Sidney Myer Charitable Trust (later Fund), was a Board member of the Royal Melbourne Hospital for four decades, and was a patron of many organisations. Pinned to Myerâ€™s dress in this portrait is her Badge of the Damehood of the Order of the British Empire, which she was awarded in 1960 for her service to the Red Cross and her tireless philanthropy for cancer and heart disease research.

papercut silhouette drawing

Purchased 2019

Â© Pamela See

In Pamela See (Xue Mei-Ling)â€™s _Making Chinese shadows (sixteen silhouette portraits)_, flowers are used as an allegory for the diasporic experience. See is a Chinese-Australian artist who questions, honours and investigates her cultural inheritance and family experience through her artistic practice. Her work connects the traditions of European silhouette portraiture and Chinese papercutting from Guangdong Province, where her motherâ€™s family originates. In the series of 16 intricate paper cuts from which these works derive, See represents members of the Chinese-Australian community who made major but often unrecognised contributions to society in the 19th century. See says of her motivation for making the portraits: â€˜these personal histories became invisible. So it wasnâ€™t just that they were excluded from parts of community life, they just were never recorded. They didnâ€™t exist, more or less.â€™ Each work incorporates a silhouette based on a photograph, an object representing their achievement, and a floral symbol of an introduced, invasive or endemic species including red silk cotton tree flower (symbolic of Guangdong Province), jasmine flower, common heath and hibiscus.

inkjet photographic print on paper

Courtesy of the artist and Vivien Anderson Gallery

Â© Naomi Hobson

Naomi Hobson worked with men from her Lockhart River and Coen communities on the Cape York Peninsula to produce these affectionate intergenerational portraits of Kaantju and Umpila boys, men and Elders. Reflecting on the impact of Christian evangelists and their imposition of restrictive gender roles, Hobson counters negative stereotypes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men in the public domain by instead affirming their capacity for caring and beauty. Through the â€˜missionisationâ€™ of First Nations peoples, much of the cultural adornment practised by Kaantju and Umpila men ceased. By photographing her male subjects decorated with flowers from the Coen area, Hobson reinvigorates this aspect of her culture and pays tribute to the nurturing compassion of Aboriginal men.

Reflecting on the impact of Christian evangelists and their imposition of restrictive gender roles, Hobson counters negative stereotypes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men in the public domain by instead affirming their capacity for caring and beauty. Through the â€˜missionisationâ€™ of First Nations peoples, much of the cultural adornment practised by Kaantju and Umpila men ceased. By photographing her male subjects decorated with flowers from the Coen area, Hobson reinvigorates this aspect of her culture and pays tribute to the nurturing compassion of Aboriginal men.

Photographer Jesse Lizotte wanted to create a portrait of Jimmy Barnes AO (b. 1956) and Jane Barnes (b. 1958) that signifies their enduring love and challenges conventional â€˜rock and rollâ€™ depictions of the singer. In this photograph, he captures the tenderness between the spouses as they lie quite literally on a bed of roses. Lizotte, who is also Jimmy and Janeâ€™s nephew, recalls asking them for references for the portrait: â€˜Jane had come to me with a French love poem, alongside a series of paintings by Chagall ... I wanted to create a floating illusion, and to incorporate the roses that Jimmy picks from their garden and arranges for Jane every day.â€™ Not just a romantic backdrop, the couple often give each other rose bushes for their garden as gifts for special occasions. The metaphor of the rose is not lost on them. Considering the flower in relation to their relationship, the couple observed: â€˜Itâ€™s not always a bed of roses. Itâ€™s not always easy, thereâ€™s thorns ... but itâ€™s about living through that and sharing those experiences.â€™

audio.title: Jimmy and Jane Barnes
audio.transcript:
**Jimmy Barnes**: We have a beautiful garden at home and friends would give me roses. We don't want gifts.

**Jane Barnes:** Yeah, for your 60th, what happened was everybody brought a rose. So we created this â€¦

**Jimmy Barnes:** Rose garden

**Jane Barnes:** â€¦ amazing rose garden.

**Jimmy Barnes:** Yeah weâ€™ve got these beautiful roses that obviously are brought to us with love and every day I'd go and pick them, roses for Jane all through lockdown. And every day I'd pick a new bunch and say, look at this, isn't this great? And they smell beautiful. And that was sort of my way of reaching out to Jane every day and letting her know I loved her. And it was a simple thing. And I just loved the fact that these roses kept growing in our garden.

**Jane Barnes:** And you could pick a hundred of them.

**Jesse Lizotte:** Well, on the day you brought like wheelbarrows full, you came into the photo studio with just tonnes of roses.

**Jimmy Barnes:** It was beautiful.

**Jesse Lizotte:** Yeah, we had too many. It smelt great.

**Jimmy Barnes:** And that whole metaphor, thereâ€™s a portrait about love and the whole metaphor of the roses and things, you know love's not always easy â€¦

**Jane Barnes:** A bed of roses.

**Jimmy Barnes:** â€¦ it's not always a bed of rose, it's not always easy â€¦

**Jane Barnes:** Its full of thorns.

**Jimmy Barnes:** ... it takes work. And there's thorns, it's not always going to be great. But it's about living through that and sharing those experiences that makes love. You know, love takes work and love takes effort and love takes... you know, you have to give and take, you know. And I thought it was â€¦

**Jane Barnes:** And adventures and wonderful things as well.

**Jimmy Barnes:** I thought it was a great metaphor with the roses. And particularly because they came from our garden. They were the roses that we've been sharing for the previous years, you know.
audio.acknowledgements: This recording was made during interviews for the National Portrait Gallery's [_Portrait Stories_][1] series.\n\n [1]: /stories

00:04:23.340 --> 00:04:24.540
by not,
<v ->You're an artist.</v>

125
00:04:24.540 --> 00:04:25.727
pursuing music.

126
00:04:25.727 --> 00:04:26.581
Well in the end,

127
00:04:26.581 --> 00:04:27.701
I, I,
<v ->Oh yeah.</v>

128
00:04:27.701 --> 00:04:28.534
<v ->Yeah.</v>
<v ->I suppose,</v>

129
00:04:28.534 --> 00:04:30.450
you know, I, yeah, like chose a creative path.

130
00:04:30.450 --> 00:04:34.351
But I remember going to the Portrait Gallery

131
00:04:34.351 --> 00:04:37.860
on school excursions and, and seeing the works

132
00:04:37.860 --> 00:04:39.240
hung on the walls and just thought it was

133
00:04:39.240 --> 00:04:42.810
so monumental, almost, you know, somewhat unattainable.

134
00:04:42.810 --> 00:04:45.030
I thought, wow, it'd be nice to see my pictures hung here

135
00:04:45.030 --> 00:04:47.520
but I could never see that happening, you know?

136
00:04:47.520 --> 00:04:49.293
And so I was very,

137
00:04:52.050 --> 00:04:53.490
I was very blessed to, you know,

138
00:04:53.490 --> 00:04:54.890
get the opportunity to shoot

139
00:04:55.860 --> 00:04:59.340
Jane and Jimmy, who were, you know, who very dear to me.

140
00:04:59.340 --> 00:05:00.890
And I'm very grateful for that.

141
00:05:04.440 --> 00:05:06.150
<v ->I find, like in this photo</v>

142
00:05:06.150 --> 00:05:07.620
there's something that's sort of the message

143
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:09.780
that I tell young singers and stuff, that,

144
00:05:09.780 --> 00:05:12.390
the best singing or the best creating you'll ever do

145
00:05:12.390 --> 00:05:13.680
comes with ease.

146
00:05:13.680 --> 00:05:16.140
And it's relaxed and it's, it's in a moment

147
00:05:16.140 --> 00:05:18.360
that's not forced or stressed or,

148
00:05:18.360 --> 00:05:20.490
and I think this, this image sort of has that

149
00:05:20.490 --> 00:05:21.753
you know, it's, it's real.
<v ->Real.</v>

150
00:05:21.753 --> 00:05:23.250
<v ->But, you know, and, and if you</v>

151
00:05:23.250 --> 00:05:25.470
if you find that peace when you, like, whether you're

152
00:05:25.470 --> 00:05:28.440
on stage or in a recording studio or in, in a photo.

153
00:05:28.440 --> 00:05:31.110
If you find that peace, it becomes easy.

154
00:05:31.110 --> 00:05:34.140
The work, work becomes,

155
00:05:34.140 --> 00:05:36.390
the passion becomes the what you love.

156
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:38.760
And it's, you know, it doesn't, it's not work anymore.

157
00:05:38.760 --> 00:05:41.943
And I think that's sort of part of what shows in that photo.

158
00:05:51.708 --> 00:05:53.058
<v ->All you need is love.</v>

159
00:05:53.058 --> 00:05:55.069
(Jane and Jimmy laughing)

160
00:05:55.069 --> 00:05:57.870
<v ->I don't know, it's a bit cheesy, but,</v>

161
00:05:57.870 --> 00:05:59.010
you know,

162
00:05:59.010 --> 00:06:00.480
love endures.

163
00:06:00.480 --> 00:06:01.950
It lasts.

164
00:06:01.950 --> 00:06:02.783
<v ->Yeah.</v>

text.content: type C photograph on Fuji Metallic paper\n\nPurchased 2025

Bidjara man Dr Christian Thompson AO has featured native flowering plants in his photographs to explore kinship, culture and connection to Country since the late 2000s. The multi-panel photograph _The Shortest Day_ depicts a large-scale flower-wall, or floral constellation, within which the artist appears partially obscured by flora. Powerfully connecting the artist to nature and history, the work enacts a dynamic dialogue about identity alongside ideas of visibility and invisibility â€“ of being seen and unseen. Through his declarative self portraiture, Thompson takes control of how First Nations people are represented, dismantling the legacies of ethnographic photography. \n\nThis is the first work that Thompson made following the failed Voice referendum of October 2023. Rather than his usual vibrant living blooms, it is an abundance of dried botanical specimens that envelop the artist. The photograph is sombre and reflective, its stillness interrupted only by the billowing ribbons. Referencing the hot desert air that Thompson fondly remembers from his childhood, the ribbons here symbolise hope in moving forward.

labels.title: HarirÅ«
labels.subtitle: Sarah Hudson
labels.medium: single channel, digital video, colour, sound, 1 minute 50 seconds.

text.content: single channel, digital video, colour, sound, 1 minute 50 seconds.\n\nÂ© Sarah Hudson

On a trip to Singapore, Aotearoa/New Zealand-based artist and researcher Sarah Hudson attempted to connect with intangible ancestors by gently â€˜shaking handsâ€™ with the native flowers and plants she encountered there. _HarirÅ«_, which roughly translated from Te reo MÄori means â€˜helloâ€™ or â€˜cheersâ€™, is a humorous response to the results of an online DNA test conducted by the artist that revealed her genetic makeup as â€˜broadly Oceanicâ€™ and â€˜Southeast Asianâ€™. In this video work, these simple and repetitive acts of attempted engagement lightheartedly address more nuanced themes of migration and identity.

labels.title: Hibiscus rosa sinensis
labels.subtitle: Angela Tiatia
labels.medium: single channel digital video, colour, silent. 1 minute 30 seconds.

text.content:
single channel digital video, colour, silent. 1 minute 30 seconds.

Courtesy of Angela Tiatia and Sullivan+Strumpf

Â© Angela Tiatia. Courtesy of Sullivan+Strumpf.

Deeply embedded in her SÄmoan heritage, much of Angela Tiatiaâ€™s work critiques the commodification of Pacific Island women in Western popular culture. In _Hibiscus rosa sinensis_ the artist appears surrounded by lush foliage in close up, a bright red hibiscus protruding from her mouth. In traditional SÄmoan culture the hibiscus, when placed behind the ear, can signify relationship status and sexual availability. Behind the right means youâ€™re looking; behind the left means youâ€™re taken. In this video work, however, Tiatia creates a counternarrative. Challenging the stereotype of the sexually alluring â€˜dusky maidenâ€™, Tiatia stares steadily at the viewer and literally eats the myth. Tiatiaâ€™s consumption of this symbolically loaded bloom is an exercise in taking power back â€“ she situates herself as protagonist and rejects the colonial gaze.

labels.title: Red Flower Wall Painting
labels.subtitle: Renee Cosgrave
labels.medium: wall painting transferred to printed wallpaper

text.content:
wall painting transferred to printed wallpaper

Courtesy of Renee Cosgrave

Â© Renee Cosgrave

Artist Renee Cosgraveâ€™s interest in form, colour, shape, space and repetition can be seen in her abstract pattern wall paintings. For _In Bloom_, Cosgrave has repurposed her 2010 installation _Red Flower Wall Painting_ as a wallpaper named _He Putiputi Kura_ (meaning â€˜some scarlet red flowersâ€™ in Te reo MÄori). The work originated as a template that the artist projected onto the wall and then painted by hand, resulting in a constellation of flowers that warped and weaved organically through the space. This undulating floral effect has here been transformed into a wallpaper that punctuates the galleries in which the _In Bloom_ exhibition is displayed. This work also sits in dialogue with Polly Borlandâ€™s photograph of Queen Elizabeth II, which features the Finnish Marimekko-brand wallpaper Unikko.
inkjet print on paper

Award-winning stage and costume designer Kristian Fredrikson worked on productions for ballet, opera, contemporary dance, theatre, film and television. He began his 40-year partnership with The Australian Ballet in 1964 and collaborated regularly with Graeme Murphy for the Sydney Dance Company (SDC), Melbourne Theatre Company and Opera Australia. On the 50th anniversary of the SDC in 2019, Murphy recollected that dancer and co-artistic director of the SDC Janet Vernon would hang Frederiksonâ€™s costume illustrations on her dressing room mirror. â€˜They were so exquisitely drawn that when she was doing her make-up and psyching up for the show, they would take her straight into the world she needed to inhabit. Itâ€™s wonderful when a costume is not something you throw on but a doorway to the character you become on stage.â€™\n\nPeter Brew-Bevanâ€™s portrait shows the designer at home, surrounded by shelves overflowing with books and CDs. Notoriously private, Fredrikson looks at the camera with one hand covering half his face.
inkjet print on paper

Choreographer and dancer Graeme Murphy AO was co-artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company (SDC) with his wife Janet Vernon AM from 1976â€“2007, helping it to become one of Australiaâ€™s most successful dance companies. At 14 he was the youngest male dancer to be accepted into The Australian Ballet School; he went on to dance with The Australian Ballet, Englandâ€™s Royal Ballet and Les Ballets FÃ©lix Blaska in France. Over the years he has created productions for companies including Opera Australia, Shanghai Ballet and the Metropolitan Opera, New York. \n\nLewis Morley took this photograph during Murphyâ€™s first year as artistic director of The Dance Company (as the SDC was then known). Over four decades with the company, Murphy created a repertoire of more than 50 works. He explained his creative process during a 2020 conversation with David McAllister: â€˜It comes out of the deepest recesses of my subconscious, my movement, and if it doesnâ€™t relate, then I donâ€™t have a continuity within.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Steven Heathcote AM is Principal Repetiteur and National Touring Associate at The Australian Ballet and was the companyâ€™s longest-serving principal artist, from 1987 to 2007. He has also appeared in the film _Maoâ€™s Last Dancer_, directed _Julius Caesar_ for Victorian Opera, and choreographed _Tosca_ for Opera Australia. When interviewed in 2016 for _The Australian Ballet: The Ballet Men Issue_, Heathcote described the physicality of dance. â€˜One of the things I always loved was that pursuit of athleticism, pushing hard physicallyâ€™ he said. â€˜I really enjoyed roles like Romeo, because itâ€™s highly physical â€“ the partnering, but then also the sword-fighting and all that boy stuff. I used to love that.â€™

video.title: Julian Kingma
video.transcript: - If I had my choice when it comes to taking portraiture, I'd rather have 45 minutes of conversation, and then jam in 15 minutes of image making because that conversation or getting to know someone lowers the temperature in the room, trust becomes a thing, then I start to conjure up ideas, and particularly if I'm in a panic 'cause I generally am in a state of panic of how I'm gonna make an interesting image. Originally, I was going to be an illustrator. So that was something that I always, always planned to do. I was never gonna do anything different, I was obsessed with illustration. So I went all through my high school years, went to art school, lasted one year in a fine art degree, and then the dark room was a side project as part of my degree, and then I got stuck into the dark room. And was just the magic of the dark room and all of a sudden, that laboriousness of illustration versus the instant gratification of photography, and it filled a big hole, filled an artistic hole, and I just went this is what I'm gonna do. And then just fortuitously there was a little tiny little ad in the newspaper before phones and it said cadetship, dark room assistant at the Herald Newspaper, and I went well, I'm just gonna make a folly out of work and I'm just gonna turn up and I'm just gonna apply for this job, and I got this job as a cadetship which is now known as an internship. And then yeah, just sort of grew from that. Yeah, so that's how the photography, like that part started. I'm such a curious person about people, and stories, and mannerisms. So before I even pick up a camera, I think I like having a conversation. That's really strange. I like hearing them talk and I watch them, and without realising, I think I'm observing those little, quiet nuances in between the big gestures, and that's the stuff that I tend to hone in on. I don't know why. I know it sounds a bit weird but it's sort of like this little trance-y moment where I go from the person walks in the room, does that, sits down, introduces themself, and then starts to relax, and then do things, and then I latch onto that, and then I hone that. It's like a dance but I try and lead the dance, I give and take. And then once they're really comfortable with me, then I start to talk about what we might do as an image, but I never go in with preconceived ideas, I know that. I'm bad if I come up with an idea and walk in 'cause it's not gonna work. I rely on what they do in front of me, and that is a cue for me. I describe my work as quiet, and I think that I look for those little, quiet gestures in between the bigger gestures like if someone's quite verbose and quite a loud talker because either that's who they are or they're insecure, I wait for that to calm down, and then I start to infiltrate my little bit, and then I hone in on that part of their personality. I try to yeah, I'll throw all that stuff aside and just put everything into that little moment, that little, tiny nuance, the quiet, little moment, which is what I love. Yeah, so that's what I'm hunting for and it is chance. It always ends up being chance. I shoot with my digital camera and the first thing that people say to me is don't you need to check the back of your screen? And I go no, 'cause it'll just throw me off my game. 'Cause if I see too much, I start to doubt myself. I think I just like living in that dream scape of I don't know what I'm gonna get, and that was the great thing about film, was you wind it on, I don't know, I think it was good? Pull the dark slide, it looked good. So I think I had that innate trust because I was lucky enough to have been trained in film and trust what was gonna come out at the other end, that you were gonna get something from those 36 frames at some point, you only need one really great shot. Whereas digital, 2000, 3000, I can't ever ... I shoot digital like I shoot film. I think people think I'm lazy and I shoot and I'm taking pictures of people digitally and I go all right, we're done, they go is that it? And I go well, was that disappointing? And I go I'm sorry if I disappointed you but I'm happy! So I still shoot digital like I'm shooting film, like it's the war and I've gotta ration it. But for me, that's where I love photography, that's where I love it. That's like watching the print come up.

labels.title: James Vu Anh Pham and Tara Jade Samaya from 'The Knowledge Between Us'
labels.subtitle: Pippa Samaya

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Dancers James Vu Anh Pham and Tara Jade Samaya have performed with major dance companies in Australia and around the world, including working together at Melbourneâ€™s Chunky Move with acclaimed Dutch choreographer Anouk Van Dijk. This image was taken during the shoot for the award-winning 60-second dance film _The Knowledge Between Us_, produced by the Samaya Wives. \n\nPippa Samaya explores the physicality of dance against the natural landscape in many of her films and photographs. Interviewed for _RealTime_ in 2017, Pippa described the role of dance in her work: â€˜dance allows me to capture things that are outside of myself and itâ€™s purely visual. Dance provided me a visual language for all those complex, inner emotional states of being human. It enabled me to express things that words canâ€™t and allows a level of empathy thatâ€™s otherwise difficult to find.â€™
inkjet print on paper

As part of the series _Lit by volcanos_, dancer Tara Jade Samaya was photographed by her wife and creative partner Pippa Samaya on a volcano in the Canary Islands during the Australian 2019â€“20 bushfires.â€˜This shoot was a reflection on being so far from home while our home was on fire. There is a suspension, dispersal, and desperation in this. It was a technical push for both of us, just using the natural world and the human body. What we achieve together in this photography of dance comes from our shared trust, language, values, aesthetic, and lives together.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Dancer and choreographer Paul White worked for over 20 years as a performer and artistic collaborator with companies around the world. Since moving to Germany to dance with Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch in 2011, he has performed with Leipzig Oper Ballet, DV8 Physical Theatre, Chunky Move, Australian Dance Theatre and the Queensland Ballet Company. â€˜I think the key to growth is following passion. Iâ€™m not driven by â€œsuccessâ€, said White in a 2014 interview with _DanceTabs_. â€˜Iâ€™m more into connecting with people, and sharing something with them through performance.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wakka Wakka/Gangulu man Andrew Toby, aka Balla Neba, is a choreographer, artist and director. â€˜I grew up in an inner-city suburb where my cultural heritage was denied,â€™ says Balla Neba. â€˜As I grew, experienced life and explored I was blessed with knowledge and wisdom imparted from Elders across the country. Using this knowledge along with my natural creative gift Iâ€™ve been able to develop a unique style of dance expression.â€™
inkjet print on paper

After dancing with the Australian Dance Theatre and the UK-based DV8 Physical Theatre, Tanja Liedtke became an award-winning choreographer. She tragically died aged 29, on the eve of becoming the youngest director of Sydney Dance Company. To commemorate Liedtkeâ€™s life and work, her partner Sol Ulbrich and fellow dancers staged a world tour of her works _Construct_ and _Twelfth Floor_. As Ulbrich noted in the 2011 film _Life in Movement_, â€˜Thereâ€™s a lot to be said for giving everyone a chance to still speak through her voice. This is the thing that theyâ€™re left with, that they hold in their bodies.â€™\n\nThis photograph was taken during Liedtkeâ€™s performance in the Australian Dance Theatreâ€™s production of _Birdbrain_, directed by Garry Stewart.
inkjet print on paper

Since meeting at a dance aged 14 and 16, Pamela and Colin have continued to bond over their love of dancing.  


â€˜Dance is very special to us because it is how we met almost 70 years ago ... the intimate old style of dancing, that is, holding close, enables us to continue to express our love for each other in this very unique way. Weâ€™re two old people who are still very much in love after almost 70 years, as a result of enjoying the love and respect of our wonderful family and friends.â€™

Pamela and Colin McPherson
inkjet print on paper

Marilyn Rowe AM OBE is a former prima ballerina and the first graduate of The Australian Ballet School to become its director, from 1999 to 2014. Promoted to Principal Artist in 1970, Rowe danced all major roles in The Australian Balletâ€™s repertoire and had several works created for her by leading international choreographers, including _Gemini_ (Glen Tetley), _The Merry Widow_ (Ronald Hynd) and _Anna Karenina_ (AndrÃ© Prokovsky). In an article for _Ausdance_ in 2000 Rowe recalled, â€˜My mother took me to my first ballet class at the age of 6. I was a very shy child, reserved, self-conscious and rather timid, but when I began dancing classes I found a new strength and confidence in myself.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wajarri Yamatji woman Telphia Joseph was photographed by Wiradjuri/Kamilaroi artist Michael Riley as part of his series of portraits capturing the vibrant First Nations arts community of Sydneyâ€™s inner west. Joseph trained as a dancer at the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association (NAISDA), established in 1976 by Carole Johnson. NAISDA has launched the careers of many First Nations dancers, including Stephen Page, former artistic director of Bangarra Dance Theatre. â€˜NAISDA is a rich place of learning and cultural connection â€¦ and continues to create tremendous young artists and Iâ€™m proud to say many are an integral part of todayâ€™s Bangarra.â€™

video.title: Michael Riley's portraits
video.transcript: Linda Burney: Looking at those pictures has taken me back to the early 80s when we were all so young, and really had no sense of the enormous lives that some of us would have. You know, it was a very different place for Aboriginal people in the 80s, but it was also a time when things were really starting to happen. I think what those photographs really demonstrate to me is a radical re-look at the way that Aboriginal people were being represented.Â I also look at every individual in the series â€“ all of them that I know, some of them that I am still very much in contact with â€“ and just think there was an alignment of the stars to bring us all together. Michael had an enormous influence on both my children. He was their uncle, and a connection between Michael and my children is very strong, so it's a very, very special photograph. And I remember Michael getting us to pose for that photograph. And I had no idea that it would become such an enduring image of the beauty that he could make. Brenda Croft: The image that day that he did with me and Dad... I can still remember that Dad's shirt had a big coffee stain on it, where he'd tipped his coffee on him. It didn't take very long. He just came in, took photographs. And I just, I love that image. You know, we used to go along to all the exhibitions that were on, around the traps. And Dad was there because he was friends with Ace, and Dad's, not bragging, but he was just really proud. And he was going 'Oh, you know, you've got to come to Michael's opening tomorrow night because you'll see an image ofÂ me and Brenda in it. Then Dad sort of wanders off somewhere and Michael's [under his breath] "Brenda, Brenda, come 'ere, come 'ere" and I went over and said "What, what" and he said 'I haven't printed it. What'll I do?" And I just said, you know, "Well if you want to make an old man happy, you'd better print it. So we did. We spent the entire night printing it in Sandy Edwards' studio, printing it by hand. So we framed it and and â€“ lucky for him â€“ Dad bought it at the opening.Â Darrell Sibosado: I actually love that image. For me, personally, it's one of the best photos I've seen of myself. It's the image that reflects me from that time, makes me think about it, you know, who I was at that time.Â So that day, I remember it was a bit organised. I kept saying yesterday I remember how disorganised Michael seemed. But this was a bit of a plan. But anyway, it was on the first floor, and we were in there, and it was quite simple. There was just him with a camera. He was so comfortable to be around. You know, even though he was quiet and everything, you knew it was a good quiet. It wasn't a quiet where he's thinking you're an idiot or anything like that. You know he's not thinking bad thoughts. And I just trusted him to do whatever he wants. So I just sat there and he took the photo and that's what came out.

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Dancer and choreographer Janet Vernon AM was co-artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company from 1976 to 2007 with her husband Graeme Murphy. In the early years they often danced together. Later, she danced with the company throughout the world, in roles and productions they had created together. In a 2015 interview with Kang Yena on _The INNERview_,Vernon said of working with dancers: â€˜Itâ€™s beautiful when you get a breakthrough. They own the movement really because no one else has done this. Itâ€™s just them and their body. I think once they can accept that, and start to feel more comfortable, itâ€™s a wonderful feeling as a dancer when you suddenly find a new way of moving, a new freedom, a new voice.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Director, choreographer and curator Gideon Obarzanek founded Victorian contemporary dance company Chunky Move, and is co-director of the New Melbourne Festival. Obarzanek began his career as a dancer with the Queensland Ballet and Sydney Dance Company before switching to choreography. As he recalled in an interview with _Dircksey_ in 2018, â€˜[Choreography] was a bit of therapy at The Australian Ballet School to restore my self-esteem. I was quite behind in that course and one of the teachers said, â€œwhy donâ€™t you apply yourself to some choreography of dancing that you think you could do well?â€ I was only really a professional dancer for five years, I moved into choreography very quickly.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Meryl Tankard AO is a dancer, choreographer, filmmaker and dance theatre director. A former dancer with The Australian Ballet and the Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch in Germany, she was also artistic director of Adelaideâ€™s Australian Dance Theatre. Renowned for her distinctive choreography, when interviewed by Paul White in 2008 for _DanceLife_, Tankard said, â€˜I look for a great openness of mind and body â€¦ For me whatâ€™s important is WHY we move ... Iâ€™m not really interested in a whole lot of great technical moves if it doesnâ€™t touch you somehow emotionally. So I guess it is about being honest and true to yourself.â€™
inkjet print on paper

At the age of sixteen Sir Kenneth Gillespie joined the Borovansky Ballet in Melbourne, before performing as a lead dancer internationally with the likes of the Royal Ballet, Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo and New York City Ballet. In 1960 he founded the Tasmanian Ballet School, where he taught a young Graeme Murphy, and established Tasmaniaâ€™s first professional ballet company in 1974. â€˜I learned dance in the small stable which Kenneth transformed into a studio,â€™ Murphy said in a 2010 interview in _The Examiner_. â€˜I loved his vision, his glamour, his refinement. He was extraordinary â€¦ Your first teacher is like your first love â€“ they leave an indelible mark on your life â€“ Kenneth Gillespie is that teacher for me.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Danish prima ballerina, choreographer and teacher HÃ©lÃ¨ne Kirsova was a founding member of the Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo. She first visited Australia on tour with the Ballets Russes in 1936, returning to Sydney two years later. In 1941 she established Kirsova Ballet, the first professional ballet company in Australia. In a 1940 _Sydney Morning Herald_ article about the opening of the school she said, â€˜there is plenty of talent here. There is also a great deal of appreciation for the ballet, and I think that appreciation can be intensified by greater knowledge of the tradition and meaning of balletâ€™. Kirsova created original ballets and was an important patron of Australian composers, set designers, artists and photographers. A similar photograph of Kirsova featuring the shadows of a rope pulley backstage, also by Dupain, as published in _The Home_ magazine in 1938.
inkjet print on paper

Anna Pavlova was principal artist of the Russian Imperial Ballet, beloved for her famed creation of _The Dying Swan_. After forming her own ballet company in 1911, Pavlova performed to great acclaim around the world. Her company of about 40 dancers made two tours to Australia in 1926 and 1929.  


As a teenager, Robert Helpmann danced with the legendary ballerina on her first Australian tour. In an interview with Hazel de Berg for the National Library of Australia he described the dedication and hard work of the great dancer: â€˜I used to go to the theatre at half past five and standing on a barely lit stage covered in woollen tights and pullovers and shawls would be this lonely figure practising â€¦ I often wonder whether the audience realised for one second the amount of work you have to do to become an Anna Pavlova.â€™ 

While Pavlova avoided the press, she commissioned leading Australian photographer Harold Cazneaux to photograph her while performing in Sydney. In this portrait she is posed backstage in costume for _Don Quixote_.

labels.title: Ngarrga Jawandaji Dancing for The Sandridge Band Performing Their Song Ngabaya (Spirit People) at the 2021 Malandarri Festival, Yanyuwa Country 2021
labels.subtitle: Benjamin Warlngundu Ellis Bayliss

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Gadrian Hoosan, a Garrwa and Yanyuwa musician and lead singer of The Sandridge Band, was photographed by Gudanji/Wambaya man Benjamin Warlngundu Ellis while performing at the 2021 Malandarri Festival in Borroloola, Northern Territory. Known for their rock/reggae blend, the musicians sing in their Garrwa and Yanyuwa languages. 

â€˜The children are dancing to our song, _Ngabaya,_ about the spirit people. Itâ€™s traditional dance, traditional song with modern music. Every time we perform everyone knows the song, everyone knows how to dance. Itâ€™s a story about the land. Theyâ€™re all connected to the land.â€™  
Gadrian Hoosan

labels.title: Wandangula Dancers & the Song People Perform Ngabaya (Spirit People) at the 2014 Malandarri Festival, Yanyuwa Country 2014
labels.subtitle: Benjamin Warlngundu Ellis Bayliss

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Wandangula dancers Linda McDinny and Rachel McDinny, and the Wandangula song people, performing at the 2014 Malandarri Festival in Borroloola, Northern Territory. â€˜This _Ngabaya_ dance, he been travel all lah [sic] way from Western Australia to my Grandmother Country,â€™ says McDinny. â€˜My Grandfather he was showing that dance for us, he was dancing with them, he was dancing and showing them kids how to dance. Thatâ€™s all they did.â€™
inkjet print on paper

At the Laura Quinkan Dance Festival in Far North Queensland, communities across the Cape York Peninsula come together to celebrate with music, dance, singing and cultural performances. Wayne Quilliam has been photographing the festival for over 20 years. â€˜Each performance is a platform of commentary, of sharing stories that have been handed down by Indigenous people since the spirits created the land,â€™ Quilliam says. â€˜The Elders share the knowledge: the young carry our hopes.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wayne Quilliam took this photograph at the You Yangs in Victoria, where dancers from across the state gathered to prepare the children for their Naming Ceremony. â€˜In its purest essence the evolution of culture connects us to Country, it inhales and exhales with us, has a heartbeat, and sings songs for all to hear,â€™ says Quilliam. â€˜Listening to the Elders share the stories with the young ones as they prepare ochre for ceremony provides connection to a new entity of self, time, place and cultural consciousness.â€™
inkjet print on paper

This photograph was captured on the Bora (initiation) ceremonial grounds at the You Yangs in Victoria, where dancers from across the state gathered to prepare children for their Naming Ceremony. â€˜This image transcends the western narrative of â€œtraditional cultureâ€, responding directly to the shared experiences of people and culture in modern society,â€™ says Quilliam. â€˜For generations our people have adapted to the constantly changing landscape. The evidence of this shines through in this young dancer practicing culture with her bionics.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Alfira Oâ€™Sullivan founded Suara Indonesia Dance in 2001. She sees one of the principles of Acehnese dance, a traditional style from Indonesiaâ€™s northern province, â€˜is to dance as one body, with one soulâ€™. Here dancers perform _Rapai Geleng_, a seated Acehnese dance that combines body percussion,hand drumming and singing. They work together to keep in rhythm, throwing the drum in the air for the next person to catch. Describing the interrelatedness of dance, Suara Indonesia dancer and choreographer Amelia Darmawan said, â€˜Dance connects your feet to the earth, your heart to each other and your soul to something greater.â€™

labels.title: Daniel Riley choreographing Hit the FloorÂ Together with QL2 dancers
labels.subtitle: Lorna Sim

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Wiradjuri dancer and choreographer Daniel Riley became the first First Nations Artistic Director of the Australian Dance Theatre in 2022. Riley began his career with Canberra youth dance company QL2 before becoming a senior artist with Bangarra Dance Theatre, from 2007 to 2018. \n\nSpeaking of the role of dance in First Nations culture in a 2021 _ABC News_ article Riley said, â€˜Iâ€™ve been able to continually explore my cultural identity and my heritage, and dance is a big part of storytelling. It doesnâ€™t matter what culture or language you speak. It is a universal language. Itâ€™s how we all connect to something. Through dance, I just found my voice.â€™

labels.title: Dance for Wellbeing 'Dancing With Alzheimers' at Belconnen Arts Centre
labels.subtitle: Lorna Sim

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Dance for Wellbeing is a program initiated by Philip Piggin at the Belconnen Arts Centre, Canberra. Jacqui Simmonds leads a Vivacity class for people living with dementia and their care partners. 

â€˜Itâ€™s all about the dancers sharing a love of movement and having a joyful interaction with their partners in a safe, inclusive space. I can see that they are being touched by the music and expressing that through their bodies. Itâ€™s a privilege to dance with them and to see them leave the class smiling, more energetic and often with a higher sense of awareness.â€™  
Jacqui Simmonds

labels.title: Brooke Lockett, Heidi Martin, Karen Nanasca and Halaina Hills, NYC
labels.subtitle: Lisa Tomasetti

text.content: inkjet print on paper

During their 2012 tour of the United Sates, The Australian Ballet dancers Brooke Lockett, Heidi Martin, Karen Nanasca and Halaina Hills performed as the infamous four cygnets in Graeme Murphyâ€™s critically acclaimed _Swan Lake_, wearing costumes designed by Kristian Fredrikson.\n\nLisa Tomasetti photographed the dancers at the busy intersection of Lexington and 6th Avenue in New York City. In Tomasettiâ€™s 2020 photobook, _The Australian Ballet on the International Stage_, Lockett recalled the challenges of such a shoot: â€˜Imagine the hustle and bustle of New York, 4 Aussie ballerinas, and a photographer with the energy to stop traffic and pedestrians to get the shot.â€™
inkjet print on paper

David McAllister AC was director of The Australian Ballet from 2001 to 2020. Over three decades with the company, McAllister was celebrated for his extraordinary performances as a dancer and led The Australian Ballet to become one of the most highly regarded dance companies in the world. In an interview with Richard Fidler in 2019 for _ABC Conversations_, McAllister described a childhood love of dance: â€˜I was always dancing around â€¦ my first memory was waiting for _Play School_ and dancing in front of the TV with tea towels tucked into my pants and spinning â€¦ it was destined that I was going to dance.â€™

labels.title: Ghenoa Gela in â€˜Winds of Woerr'
labels.subtitle: Gregory Lorenzutti

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Ghenoa Gela is a proud Torres Strait Islander woman and award-winning multi-disciplinary, multi-dimensional storyteller. â€˜What I love most about dance is that it transcends time,â€™ says Gela. â€˜For _Winds of Woerr_, Mum and I connected with a story from our past, _Woerr,_ a sacred rock. By combining _Woerr_ and the _Four Seasonal Winds_ we created a new contemporary story in the present. And by sharing the knowledge and story through dance, we have created a connection to the future.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Yumi Umiumare is a Japanese Butoh dancer, choreographer and teacher. This image was taken during a dress rehearsal of _ZeroZero_, a dance work in collaboration with Tony Yap and Matthew Gingold performed at the 2014 Melbourne Festival. â€˜I remember the moment when Gregory got close to me and took this shot,â€™ says Umiumare. â€˜I felt quite fragile as Iâ€™d been very busy with many arts projects, slightly overwhelmed both mentally and physically. But when touching the clean water and seeing my reflection, this sensation shifted to a gentle feeling of relief and calmness melting into the image of my own face.â€™

labels.title: Dancenorth Australia (Gideon Obarzanek & Lucy Guerin) Samantha Hines, Mason Kelly, Jenni Large, Ashley McLellan, Josh Mu, Georgia Rudd and Jack Ziesing
labels.subtitle: Gregory Lorenzutti

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Choreographed by Gideon Obarzanek and Lucy Guerin, _Attractor_ brought together Queenslandâ€™s Dancenorth Australia with Indonesian music duo Senyawa. 

â€˜This work for me has been a succumbing to the inherent power of music and dance and how they can propel each other into heightened states of energy, tone, rhythm and form. I have always believed that we can watch dance without having to translate it into a meaning beyond what we see and experience.â€™  
Lucy Guerin

labels.title: Collaboration â€“ Sam Goraya, \nSantosh Ram and Samir Kumar Panigrahi backstage before a performance of Kundalini: The Awakening!
labels.subtitle: Zlatko Varenina

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Sam Goraya, Santosh Ram and Samir Kumar Panigrahi keep the Indian classical dance Odissi alive through performances such as _Kundalini â€“ The Awakening!_ Here they are pictured applying makeup before a show at the Melbourne Theatre Company.\n\nâ€˜Putting make up on and getting into a character reflects how we take on different roles in our daily life and perform to the best of our abilities to achieve a harmonious outcome,â€™ says Goraya. â€˜A collaborative approach to achieve a common goal by providing guidance and support to one another as one does in real life within family and friends.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wangkatjungka actor and dancer Ningali Lawford-Wolf began her career with the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre, before joining Bangarra Dance Theatre. She tragically died while on tour with the Sydney Theatre Companyâ€™s adaptation of Kate Grenvilleâ€™s _The Secret River_. A cultural consultant and artistic collaborator with Bangarra, Lawford-Wolfâ€™s legacy was honoured in their 2021 production _SandSong,_ co-choreographed by Frances Rings. In an article by Steven Dow for _The Guardian_ in 2021, Rings said of Lawford-Wolf, â€˜She was so proud of her country; she loved her country â€¦ She was naturally gifted. I wish I could have made the shapes she made. She had long legs, she was statuesque, and she looked beautiful.â€™

audio.title: Ningali Lawford-Wolf
audio.transcript:
(Ms Lawford-Wolf speaking in language)

I was sick and tired of white portrayal of Aboriginal people. And I wanted to write a theatre that was different, had all different forms of acting in it whether it be music, dance, singing, a monologue. And I wanted to stay in the traditional way of storytelling but make it real, make it different. And the only way, and the only way I can do stories like that was to fall back on myself and my plays, like â€˜You know, youâ€™ve got a story yourself, youâ€™ve been to Alaska when you were 16, you know, you lived here, you lived there, youâ€™ve come from Christmas Creek station, youâ€™ve come up from nowhere and make a name for yourself in the acting world and that is an achievement for someone my age. And I never really thought about it because I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m anything special. I donâ€™t know, Iâ€™m still quite naive in that aspect.

I wanted to make it honest too, â€˜cos you look at a lot of Aboriginal people that are working out there, thereâ€™s a lot of Aboriginal women that are working but not really strong Aboriginal womenâ€™s stories. And I wanted to make my point of view as a woman and as a proud Aboriginal woman, proud of where I come from, whether than be the backblocks of Woop Woop but yet that place still has a very big significance for me. I wanted to make Australia realise that they do have an Indigenous culture in Australia. They have it here. No, no, and Australia doesnâ€™t need to go anywhere else and adopt someone elseâ€™s Indigenous culture which a lot of people tend to do. But, you know, they have it here. And nobody hasnâ€™t discovered it, itâ€™s so funny going to Europe, for me, and more European people know more about Aboriginal Australia than Australians do so which is quite sad, which is really really quite sad. It goes to show how ignorant white Australia is.
audio.acknowledgements: Reproduced by permission of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation â€“ Library Sales. Awaye Â© 1996 ABC.

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Max Dupainâ€™s glamorous photographs of dancers, such as this portrait of ballerina Tamara Tchinarova, capture the excitement and impact of the three avant-garde Russian ballet companies that toured Australia in the late 1930s. Tchinarova first came to Australia with the Monte Carlo Russian Ballet in 1936. During that tour she was elated when ballet critic Arnold Haskell, writing for Melbourneâ€™s _Table Talk_, described her performance as â€˜brilliantâ€™, noting her â€˜aristocratically energetic movementâ€™. Tchinarova remained in Sydney after a second tour with Covent Garden Russian Ballet in 1938. During the 1940s she danced with three Australian companies, the Kirsova Ballet, the Polish-Australian Ballet and the Borovansky Ballet.
inkjet print on paper

Dancer, choreographer, actor and filmmaker, Sir Robert Helpmann CBE was co-director then director of The Australian Ballet from 1965â€“76. During his celebrated career, Helpmannâ€™s dance partners included English ballerina Margot Fonteyn and Soviet-born ballet dancer Rudolf Nureyev. He was renowned for his innovative choreography, such as his iconic 1964 ballet _The Display_, in which Barry Kitcher starred as the _Lyrebird_. As Kitcher reflected in his 2001 book _From Gaolbird to Lyrebird_: â€˜An infusion of excitement, apprehension and nerves spread through the new company as we awaited the arrival of Robert Helpmann â€¦ His formidable authority and flamboyant personality were legendary.â€™  


This photographic montage resulted from David Mooreâ€™s short sitting with Helpmann in his Sydney hotel room in 1969. The cramped space limited Mooreâ€™s creative options, so he took these silhouettes against the window.

audio.title: Robert Helpmann
audio.transcript: By this time the English ballet was growing in impetus and the houses were getting bigger and I was getting more than favourable press and Markova and I had formed a great partnership. Markova then decided to leave and start her own company with Anton Dolin. And I thought, â€˜Well this is the end of the balletâ€™, when Ninette de Valois said, â€˜Iâ€™ve found a girl that youâ€™re going to dance withâ€™, and took me into the classroom and I said, â€˜Which one?â€™ She said, â€˜That one over there with the two long plaitsâ€™, and I thought, â€˜That funny-looking little girl?â€™ and I said, â€˜Whatâ€™s her name?â€™ and she said, â€˜Peggy Hookhamâ€™, and I said, â€˜Well, thatâ€™s not going to look very good on the notice board is it, Peggy Hookham?â€™ And I said, â€˜She looks Chineseâ€™. And she said, â€˜Well as a matter of fact, she was born in Shanghai but she is English. No, she was born in Reigate and she went to Shanghai as a little girl â€“ I want you to work with herâ€™. And the minute, of course, I saw her dance, I realised that she was absolutely wonderful, and Ninette said, â€˜Sheâ€™s going to change her name, sheâ€™s going to call herself Margot Fonteynâ€™. And so from that moment on, I danced with Fonteyn for 27 years and I suppose we became, at that time, the most famous pair dancing in Europe.\n\nIâ€™m always asked what was the most memorable performance or production, and itâ€™s impossible really for me to say, because so many things have been memorable to me. My first appearances with Markova, my first appearances with Fonteyn, my first appearances with Vivienne Leigh, the first time I played _Hamlet_, all of them. I have never felt for one minute in my life, â€˜Iâ€™m a successâ€™. I feel Iâ€™ve accomplished something and that is done and therefore there is something more to do. The success or failure of what has passed has passed and I must go on to something else. And whatever else I may have achieved in life, I hope that people will remember that my whole life has been dedicated to producing something of beauty in the theatre.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Robert Helpmann is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Tammi Gissell is a Murruwarri dancer, choreographer and performance theory scholar. In a 2018 article in _The Canberra Times_ Gissell discussed the layered significance of dance in First Nations culture: â€˜Everyone dances. But for us itâ€™s not how we dance, or what we dance, but why we dance. In Aboriginal society, knowledge has always been passed from body to body. Dance is a way of making sense of the world. It is the storehouse of our knowledge, and the way we pay respect to our heritage. If knowledge is not passed on, the balance of our world becomes unhinged. Dancing is a matter of survival for Aboriginal culture.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Jianna Georgiou is a dancer, choreographer and director with Adelaideâ€™s Restless Dance Theatre, a company for dancers with and without disability that celebrates diversity and fosters inclusivity. Since joining Restless in 2006, Georgiou has performed in productions around the country, including _Seeing Through Darkness_ (pictured here) at the Art Gallery of South Australia.\n\nâ€˜When I start dancing on stage, it gives me light and life,â€™ says Georgiou. â€˜As an artist I communicate with others through my body.â€™

labels.title: Beau Dean Riley Smith, Wiradjuri and Gamilaraay nations, Bennelong
labels.subtitle: Jacob Nash

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Wiradjuri and Gamilaraay dancer, choreographer and actor Beau Dean Riley Smith was photographed by Daly River artist Jacob Nash backstage in the paint-up room, preparing for his performance in the title role of Bangarra Dance Theatreâ€™s _Bennelong_. Reserved for the dancers, the paint-up room is a sacred space where ochre is applied to the body as an expression of cultural identities and histories. Nash also designed the sets for _Bennelong_ while head of design at Bangarra. Both men  
won Helpmann Awards for this production.  


â€˜Song, dance and visual art all exist together within one story,â€™ says Nash. â€˜My relationship to the design of the show, to these dancers, to this paint up room and these portraits â€“ the whole thing informs me. Itâ€™s the blood. These guys are the storytellers and Iâ€™m in this room seeing them become those characters, moments, spirits.â€™

Wiradjuri and Gamilaraay dancer, choreographer and actor Beau Dean Riley Smith was photographed by Daly River artist Jacob Nash backstage in the paint-up room, preparing for his performance in the title role of Bangarra Dance Theatreâ€™s _Bennelong_. Reserved for the dancers, the paint-up room is a sacred space where ochre is applied to the body as an expression of cultural identities and histories.
